Some of the characters were a little underdeveloped, because of the complexity of the plot, but what you lack in development you more than make-up in implied backstory.

If you didn't know this movie deals with race relations. It was interesting to watch this movie in an audience that was diverse. Some of the more prevalent stereotypes in our society was explored. They were not explored in an ABC after school special way, it was explored with very graphic imargery and language. It is a reason this movie garnered an R rating. I really feel that the language used in this movie was needed, to understand the depth of the issues dealt with. Many of my Christian readers will be offended by this language and a brief sex scene, but I think you should go see the movie anyway, because the story is bigger than that. Remember the Passion got an R rating too! This is best movie of 2005 to date. I would have given it a 10 rating, but I didn't want to eat that if something greater came out this year. But this is a remarkable film that I feel every one should see. This movie will make you think twice about your own life and whether or not you are making unjust stereotypes on another race or even your own race.

M.L.K. dream is still not complete and this movie helps to show us how we can make it happen. Go Crash into your favorite theatre to see this movie.

I give this movie a 10, because it will go down in cinematic history! And it will win an Oscar!

title: Poignant, heartfelt drama
review:
A terse, compelling multi-threaded plot that has some of the most heart-wrenching moments I've experienced in film. The characters and their story lines are so economically etched that there is not a second of "Crash" that does not drive the story forward. There is a key scene in each story line that, if you're not totally gripped by the throat, then you either haven't been paying attention, or you don't have a human heart.

"Crash," like any multi-plotted film (ex: "Gosford Park," "Traffic," "The Hours," "Amores Perros") requires diligence on the audience's part -- this is not "Die Hard" or "Lethal Weapon" (both great films) -- but the cost of entry is merely perceptive viewing, and the payoff is huge.

title: LA CRASH Review
review:
The film "LA Crash" directed by Paul Haggis in the year 2004 is about the metropolitan problems of the city Los Angeles like racism, crime and corruption. It shows different faces and interests through the movie of ethnically different persons with their own little problems. It's like you see the happenings through various points of view. The viewer gets empathy on every single character. Therefore I give it a 8/10. Also the cinematography is in important scenes very haunting and therefore on point.

Its for a school project :)

title: Fools attracted to shiny things
review:
A movie with a message should present it with respect, clarity and responsibility. Movies like Get Out, Do The Right Thing, 13th and even (as silly as it is) Zootopia and various kids shows present these themes about race in some sort of respectable or, at the very least, in a thrilling, engaging way that leaves the audience stunned or a bit smarter when the credits roll. A movie that gets its point across without being an inconsistent mess.

Crash isn't one of those movies. In fact, it's the movie delivers its message in the most rough, uncomfortable and most obvious way possible without carrying about anything else in the movie including its characters and it's plot.

This is a movie so abominably and unapologetically horrible that it shocks me that to this day, people enjoy this garbage. There are literal Sesame Street episodes who present the same message in a better, more adult way than this rated R, indie, Academy Award winning flick with stars all over the production.

This characters (for the most parts) are one dimensional, cardboard cut out, generic stereotypes of the races and group represented. There is a twist where 2 black people talking about how their viewed as menaces who people are afraid and that they should be more scared because of everything else and that they're just normal people, mere seconds before they pull out guns and robs the state attorney car. The movie is trying to prove a point to not stereotype everyone but using those same stereotypes as our characters and its driving force for the plot. None of it is realistic in any shape, way or form. The only thing you get from these people is that they're just douches who are racist in one way or another (except Michael Pena's characters but we'll get to him) and they have a half baked change of heart through an event knocking some sense into them.

The technical filmmaking (i.e lighting, editing, and cinematography) would be fine but then you realized that it won an Oscar and you realize "what?, how?". The editing just consists of basic, film school entry level transitions and cuts with some other ones consisting of pretentious shots carried by the generic, pretentious, operatic score. The score does absolutely nothing but try to hammer in how flashy it is with the same tune used over and over like in the part where Sandra Bullock falls down stairs or how its used when Michael Pena's daughter is shot and its supposed to be dramatic, instead of hilarious due to the editing.

Let's talk about those 2 for a second, Sandra Bullock plays a racist, rich, white woman who's the district attorney's wife. She's racist because of the incident of the carjacking and says some racist things due to anger, falls down some stairs, hispanic housekeeper takes her to the hospital and is not racist. This is basically the end of most subplots from this movie. They either end like that or just abruptly end at the climax like Michael Pena's subplot. Also, was there not a single other take for that scene. You're telling after days and days of working on the movie and editing it, nobody decided to use a better take or tell the director something isn't right? Did nobody explode in laughter when they rewatched the footage and see how terribly and hilariously flawed it is and shouldn't be altered in a better and a serious way. It's possibly the worst scene in the movie by far with a character who doesn't really seem to be bad and good since he's done nothing really racist.

Most reviews on here on talking about "at the end of day, everybody's good and bad', but that's clearly not what's trying to scream at the choir. In one scene Ryan Phillipe's character (a rookie cop) is in a car with Larenz Tate's character and because of suspicion that he has a gun and a fit over country music (no kidding) and decided to just burn the car that they were in and hide the body and then it just ends. It's like if you were downloading something and then (at 97%) it just cut off.

To describe Crash in simpler terms is to describe a rich entitled prick named... Amy, she's the most well known girl across the school, she's very rich gaining a lot of unneeded things Lambo's and jewelry. She's also in the cheerleading team and despite her being the worst and weakest out of all them, she still gets undeserved praise and awards for no reason other than she's popular. She also couldn't care less about anything the next one night stand or how she's "getting fatter". The only time she does care is to talk about how white people/men are bad and refusing to delve more into topics other than the basic shallow level knowledge that everyone else feed her. She just says a couple of words and then leaves

title: Beyond Masterpiece!
review:
If you've been searching for the most complete and perfect representation of what so many people in the West actually think, this movie would be it. A perfectly crafted, paint-by-numbers path to race relations in the West but, primarily in the US. There is no way any decent human being can watch this and not come away moved or shaken by the extremely deep and visceral NPC programming portrayed in this film. If you want to really understand the lens by which our betters see our nation then you're going to NEED to watch first Birth of a Nation, then Crash. title: Human Ego Explained!

title: Crash (2004)
review:
Most people would agree that America is obsessed with race, certainly its politicians of a certain political bent are. This film is set in Los Angeles only a decade after the O.J. Simpson double murder trial, and before that the disgraceful Rodney King incident which was followed by the even more disgraceful Los Angeles riots after the acquittal of King's uniformed assailants. All the same it is difficult to believe that all the principal characters would have been as obsessed with race as they are portrayed in this film, and it isn't only the whites who are bigots.

Weird happenstances and outrageous coincidences happen every day, but those herein beggar belief, and would a police officer really have sexually assaulted a woman in front of both her husband and his own partner during a traffic stop? In 1985, Anthony Pacho was indicted for fondling shoplifting suspects; although the former Glendale police officer would eventually plead guilty at Los Angeles Superior Court to lesser charges, it is most doubtful if a veteran officer would have jeopardised his pension with the sort of outrage depicted here two decades on.

As for the redemption in this film, bad people can do good things, and do all the time. Alas, there is no redemption for some, including the people behind "Crash".

title: An entertaining film about racism
review: Though it can be preachy and a bit overwritten at times, Crash is still a wonderfully honest and intricate examination on modern racism bolstered by an affecting score and editing, and a tremendous ensemble cast.

title: Love movies which make you want to re-watch them
review:
Race is paramount in this film, and all our preconceptions of who people are get twisted and turned through the intricate plot. With each new additional character we find another assumption, another stereotype, and then watch as that preconception is obliterated as the character develops. It is a credit to the deftly written script, tight direction and exceptional acting talent that every one of these many characters is fully realized on screen without ever feeling one-dimensional.

I would love to discuss some of the details of what happens to explain how well it is done, but part of the magic of this film is allowing yourself to be taken on this ride. Mind you, this isn't a ride of pleasure. The first half of this film is unrelentingly in its ferociousness. I could literally feel my rage at some of the characters forming to a fever pitch. The fear and hatred I was confronting wasn't just on the screen, but in the pit of my stomach. And in one absolutely brilliant moment I was literally sobbing at the expectation of horror unfolding, only to be cathartic-ally released in a most unexpected way.

Mr. Haggis was in attendance at the screening I saw and explained that the idea for this film came to him one night sometime after 9/11 at about 2 a.m. when his own memories of a car- jacking experience from 10 years before wouldn't leave him alone. Clearly this film was his way of relieving those demons of memory, using the catharsis of his art to unleash them and in doing so has given to all viewers of cinema an opportunity to examine our own preconceptions about race relations and how we treat each other and think of ourselves. He mentioned in the discussion after-wards that he likes to make films that force people to confront difficult issues. Films that ask people to think after the film has ended and not just leave saying: "that was a nice film".

title: Dramatic, but confusing too.
review:
There are some really good scenes, and some great lines. But I had trouble trying to follow who was who, and what was going on. It is hard to say what the movie is about. Maybe a line from a voice-over helps, something like "People here don't talk to each, they crash into each other and then talk"? There are lots of crashes, mostly attitude-attitude as well as physical.

There is a nose-tail car incident very early on which is repeated at the very end. It is perhaps supposed to sum up the whole idea? Then there is the good-cop/bad-cop display. The bad cop gropes a woman and then saves her life from a car flip. The good cop can't cope with the bad cop and tries to get transferred, but runs up against ingrained issues at the precinct and later makes a bad, bad mistake, the consequences of which are not explored.

How many main actors are there? Many, mostly very good, ie, the locksmith, his wee daughter, the shopkeeper, his daughter, the cop's sick dad, the medical receptionist.

Having shown us the complicated side of life in Los Angeles, the movie fails to resolve anything, or am I expecting too much? Probably.

title: Well Acted, albeit a Messy, Underwhelming Story,
review:
Crash is a good movie with a reasonably well developed storyline and a terrific cast. The main part of this movie that made it worth the watch have to be the actors, they all play very real, convincing characters, there's not a single weak performance here, and I'm surprised more of them weren't Oscar nominated. It is lacking when it comes to a compelling story, which is clearly what this movie wanted to be, but because we are following so many different characters it becomes hard to feel for any as they are all underdeveloped, there's not a single character who's potential felt fully used. As far as Best Picture winners go, it lacks originality, there's not a single story that we haven't seen in another movie, or a character that feels fresh, it's too dedicated to being realistic that it forgets to offer something exciting or different for its audience. I certainly don't think Crash deserved a Best Picture Academy Award as its too flawed, but it's a very well acted drama, certainly worth the watch if you ever see it on television or Netflix.

Following the events of a car crash, we follow a group of characters in their interconnected lives.

Best Performance: Terrence Howard

title: tutti fruity!
review: Wow, I saw this movie last night on TV and the more I think of it the more I like it. I'm amazed at the divergence of opinions I can find in the reviews (only read a few but that sample was enough to show me some extreme thoughts on it) I'd love to write but don't really know how to, this is confirmed here by some very well written reviews. I must add, mainly the positive ones, some of the others somehow seem too bitter for me to... But I felt quickly this was an intelligent and honest account of what happens in a multi culture society...Funny the night before I saw an episode of George Gently based around racial prejudice, however this movie reachess much further and points out, regardless of their origin, people aren't 100% good of bad. Well this can also mean there is always a fork on your road and things will differ as you take either of those paths. title: Definitely not best picture, but still an interesting look at struggling lives.
review: Paul Haggis' "Crash" is a thoughtful look at the lives of multiple citizens of Los Angeles who, by chance and unprepared circumstances, collide and interact with each other, leaving their lives changed forever, good or bad. This is the kind of movie you feel both good and bad after viewing due to the harsh experiences each character endures, but also due to a hopeful message that Haggis leaves you with. "Crash" won't be on your all-time favorites list, but it'll give you a lot to think about and feel. Each performance is filled with power and dedication, leaving you filled with opinion towards each man and woman who you get to know for a brief amount of time. That's one of the issues: too many characters. The film had a lot of room to add more drama and tension if it toned down the over-usage of characters and focused on its message and purpose: people struggle still due to race and social class every day.

title: One of the few good movies on Racial theme!!!!
review: Issues of race and gender cause a group of strangers in Los Angeles to physically and emotionally collide in this drama from director and screenwriter Paul Haggis. Graham (Don Cheadle) is a police detective whose brother is a street criminal, and it hurts him to know his mother cares more about his brother than him. Graham's partner is Ria (Jennifer Esposito), who is also his girlfriend, though she has begun to bristle at his emotional distance, as well as his occasional insensitivity over the fact he's African-American and she's Hispanic. Rick (Brendan Fraser) is an L.A. district attorney whose wife, Jean (Sandra Bullock), makes little secret of her fear and hatred of people unlike herself. Jean's worst imaginings about people of color are confirmed when her SUV is carjacked by two African-American men -- Anthony (Chris Bridges, aka Ludicrous), who dislikes white people as much as Jean hates blacks, and Peter (Larenz Tate), who is more open minded. Cameron (Terrence Howard) is a well-to-do African-American television producer with a beautiful wife, Christine (Thandie Newton). While coming home from a party, Cameron and Christine are pulled over by Officer Ryan (Matt Dillon), who subjects them to a humiliating interrogation (and her to an inappropriate search) while his new partner, Officer Hansen (Ryan Phillippe), looks on. Daniel (Michael Pena) is a hard-working locksmith and dedicated father who discovers that his looks don't lead many of his customers to trust him. And Farhad (Shaun Toub) is a Middle Eastern shopkeeper who is so constantly threatened in the wake of the 9/11 attacks that he decided he needs a gun to defend his family. Crash was the first directorial project for award-winning television and film writer Haggis.

title: Good Film, But Rather Blunt
review:
Los Angeles citizens with vastly separate lives collide in interweaving stories of race, loss and redemption.

When this film came out, it was a huge success, both critically and with the general viewer. Looking back a decade later (in 2014), the reason for this is somewhat obscure. Although the film looks great, is well-directed, and has a cast with more than a dozen big names, it is hampered by some rather shoddy writing.

Not five minutes go by without someone making a racist comment. Now, of course, this is the point: to show us how racism is going strong in the 21st century, and it is not just black versus white. But the way it is shown here is just so blunt that it takes away any sort of artistic merit and just makes the film a moralizing, proselytizing screed. A very good one, but still just so solidly plain.

title: Great acting overall in a striking story
review: I saw Third Person (2013) before this one. Paul Haggis really is good in creating such intricate web of stories combined into one big story. But compared to Third Person (2013), the grand theme in this movie is much more serious and engaging. the movie also concludes nicely for all the characters, mainly turning their long established mindsets upside down and forcing them to acknowledge the reality of an unfair world by doing something that is paradoxical to their principles. The acting job in overall is a great job. With a list of first tier actors and actresses, this makes it even better. The greater thing is that there is equal share of focus and screen-time for each significant characters. For me, Ludicrous' performance is the one which shined out the most within the circumstances.

title: Good
review:
The setup: Los Angeles citizens with vastly separate lives collide in interweaving stories of race, loss and redemption.

The verdict: This is another level of film. I can watch this film over and over again. All through the movie, there are moments where you fear that its makers are going to settle for the clich√©, but you know what? They never do. This is a story about a place most people might not be able to conceive. All the characters struggle against a system that has perpetuated falsehoods. It's not the thing to see if you're in the mood for something uplifting, or something with tons of thrills and action, but it is solid.

title: A Flawed Gem!
review:
'Crash' is A Flawed Gem! Though Not worthy enough to have Won Best Picture at the Oscars, it still has some strong merits.

'Crash' Synopsis: Los Angeles citizens with vastly separate lives collide in interweaving stories of race, loss and redemption.

'Crash' is partly astonishing, partly bland. Its a strange film in many ways, as some of its episodes leave a remarkable impression, while some appear tasteless. I was particularly impressed by the chapter involving a racist white police officer, (played by an astounding Matt Dillon), who disgusts his more idealistic younger partner. Another chapter which is interesting is the one involving a black detective, (played by Don Cheadle), who's estranged from his mother; his criminal younger brother and gang associate. The rest of the chapters are either passable or under-whelming.

Paul Haggis & Robert Moresco's Screenplay has its pluses & minuses. Haggis's Direction, on the other-hand, is decent. Cinematography is classy. Editing is fairly done.

Performance-Wise: Of its mammoth cast, its Matt Dillon who steals the show. He enacts the racist cop who later comes in terms with his humanity, with brilliance. He very worthily was Nominated for an Oscar. Another impressive performance comes from Thandie Newton. She's excellent. The rest of the cast, enact their parts with sincerity.

On the whole, 'Crash' is not a masterpiece, but an impressive watch nevertheless.

title: Very Eye Opening
review: This film is very good, and very eye opening. It is thought provoking and makes you stop and think before you make assumptions about people. It shows you that every person has a story, and a life and their skin color does not make them who they are. People who say that this film is horrible or unrealistic are ignorant bigots who don't know about the realism of racism to this very day. One if the biggest mind-boggling scenes for me, the scene that made the point of this film hit home, was when Peter Waters (Larenz Tate) was trying to show Officer Tom Hansen(Ryan Phillippe) the he carried the same figurine that was sitting in the Officer's car and Waters(Tate) got shot simply because he was black and Hansen(Phillippe) was scared that he had a gun. Very emotional, very satisfying, very alarming.

title: It's gray, it's chaos, it's life.
review:
First of all, Many users have harshly reviewed this celluloid on IMDb, and that's unfortunate. Either they didn't get it (which is acceptable) or they are trying to separate themselves from the general crowd who loved the movie (which sucks & Don't fall for it).

I loved this film. It is simply amazing. I won't try to use grandiloquent language to share my experience. In short, the film will give you a tour of life in 2hrs. I learned a lot from it. The film has some brilliant gray characters which are beautifully portrayed, and that's life..Everybody we meet is gray..Evereybody is a combo of good and bad. The movie might will blow you away by its magical simulation of chaos and how one event leads to another. It depicts the intertwined lives of people and how chaos affects them. The movie might will help you in several ways..It provokes a lot of disturbing questions which we all need to answer. It would make you introspect your mind using these questions. There are many things in life which we do or which happen to us that we can't let out..we bury them inside, and those things gradually make us weak. This movie might help those people who carry such baggage. it'll make you understand that there are things which are beyond your control and you don't have to blame yourself for every single thing that happens to you. So I say take it easy..Watch this movie and stop being cynical (if you're). I would recommend it to each and every movie buff.

PS- The movie won't offer anything to people who are looking for entertainment..(Though, I found it highly entertaining).

title: loved it
review: First of all I would like to say congratulations to a film that dares to take on a subject that these days is like pointing at the elephant in the room and calling him big nose.But to make a point, this is not only a film about racism but a film about peoples differences and importantly their point of view..SPOILER......Sandra Bullock s role highlights this when she realises that the only person who genuinely cares for her is her housemaid. ..(personally the most touching part of the film) oh and brilliantly underplayed by Sandra B...This film really surprised me because some scenes seemed to tap in to moments that I have witnessed with my own eyes and..OK OK maybe exaggerated for story telling purposes to a degree but the essential point being still made loud and clear.Some viewers more than others need clearer , more obvious story telling than others. ..All in all a very clever movie with a great point to make...

title: Heart of Controversy
review:
I will admit, Crash is a very emotional movie. It depicts the lives of strangers and how we're all so connected yet distant from our neighbours. Racism is at the centre of this movie, and prejudice seems to cause countless problems in everyone's lives in one way or another. There's constant battles between doing good or bad and overall, this film is definitely entertaining both on a superficial and mental level.

Although Crash was a very interesting movie, I felt the amount of drama was overdone and it almost seemed artificial at instances. Don't get me wrong; there certainly were moments of genuine panic and relief. But at specific moments, I could easily distinguish the storyline as fabricated when I really shouldn't have been able to, and this reduced its otherwise strong relatability.

The acting in this film was excellent. Performances from actors like Michael Pe√±a and Matt Dillon really pulled this film together and were by far some of my favourite scenes. The perfect settings and contrast between different lives really give this movie an edge and is the reason I, among many others, truly enjoyed this film from beginning to end.

I definitely think the racial themes addressed in this film were very revealing--though arguably a little plastic--and helped relate this movie with modern times. I am glad I watched this film since it shows the stark disparities between two individuals, and it highlights the numerous parallels as well.

title: Great Acting, Fantastic Scriptwriting
review: This film didn't really seem like my cup of tea, but I kept it on and really got into it. There is some really fantastic performances in this film. I really liked the way all the different people's lives were interlinked. Although I really thought the film was going to end on a downer, I was happy that some of the stories turned out well. Especially the locksmiths story it was a huge relief to find out his daughter wasn't accidentally killed. I thought Sandra Bullocks character was far too outwardly racist and don't really think there would be anyone that vocal about it. Their story was probably the worst. Don Cheadle got what was coming for him and Ludicrous' story ended with a nice touch.

title: This Is Deep!
review:
I have watched many films in my life, yet for some reason this one has eluded me for quite some time. Anyway I finally decided to watch it and boy am I glad I did.

"Crash" beautifully mixes racism in society and combines it with the butterfly effect (for those who may not know the butterfly effect is the belief that a small change in one place can lead to an overall big change), to give an incredibly interesting look in to attitudes on race in society. There was honestly not a moment in this film in which I was bored, but there was a sex scene within in the film which I didn't understand the purpose of as it didn't feel like it belonged or was even related to the rest of the movie.

All of the actors play their parts incredibly well, I was particularly impressed with Sandra Bullock as well as Ludicrous as it felt like they totally embodied their roles. You truly end up caring for all the characters and understanding what they have to deal with from their point of view and yes awful things do happen to some of them. Yet the movie doesn't beat you over the head with it's message, it lets you come to your own conclusions. Is this movie totally depressing?, No. is it thought provoking?, Yes no other movie has made me think about myself as a human being more than this. It may be hard to find but Crash is a movie about progress and within its message there is Hope.

Now the only reason for which I have not awarded this movie a 10 which in all honesty it probably deserves, is simply due to the movie poster. For some reason whoever made this particular poster decided to give away a major plot detail. That is all. Other than that it is the perfect film.

title: The major theme reflected on racism and the social perception.
review:
The 2004 film Crash takes the audience on a roller coaster ride through the lives of many characters. The film, co-written, produced and directed by Paul Haggis reflects on the racial and social tensions in Los Angeles, California. The film stars, Graham Walters (Don Cheadle) and Ria (Jennifer Esposito) who play police detectives in the film, who are dating and intertwined with Peter (Larenz Tate) who is Graham's brother in the film. The film also includes Rick Cabot (Brendan Fraser) and his wife Jean (Sandra Bullock) who are carjacked by Anthony (Chris "Ludscris" Bridges) and Peter (Larenz Tate). Also starring in the film are John Ryan (Matt Dillon) and his partner Tom Hansen (Ryan Phillippe) who are corrupt Los Angeles police officers. Additionally, Cameron Thayer (Terrence Howard) and his wife Christine (Thandie Newton) are pulled over by John, after the two display unusual behavior while driving. The story reflects on the lives of all these characters, how they are all connected, and how racism is relevant in today's society.

The major theme reflected on racism and the social perception. The movie placed a great deal of emphasis on racism, including scenes of Daniel (Michael Pena) going into a store and being treated badly because of his race and tattoos by store owner Farhad (Shaun Toub), while attempting to buy a gun. The two have an altercation, and Daniel leaves the store. Irony plays a part in the scene where Anthony and Peter are walking down the sidewalk and the two discuss how they were victims of racism and poor service based on their skin color. Shortly after having this discussion, the two hijack a SUV driven by Rick Cabot with his wife Jean as the passenger. The story begins to unfold and you begin to see the connection between the characters.

While watching the film, I recall having a similar feeling while watching American History X. Primarily, because of the strong emphasis placed on racism. There is often a lesson to be learned in dealing with movies that focus so much attention on racism and the perception that society accepts this behavior.

The motif of the film was relevant throughout, and related to the theme in the aspect that racism was consistently displayed. The lighting, often times dark and somber, also played into the theme. Racism is not bright and cheery, it is disturbing and dark.

Though this movie contained a high dose of reality in what people go through on a daily basis, it did so with ease. Even though the characters were divided, they were still somehow connected.

title: "You think you know who you are? You have no idea"
review: The gray area of prejudiced behavior and blatant racism plays across the volatile melting pot that is Los Angeles. The white elephant (pun intended) is bold, provocative and, except for plot run-ins and tie-ins, very un-Hollywood-like. Various angles paint a very un-black and white picture where racism is neither attacked or defended. It's just laid out as one big question. Where does common sense end and racism begin? The concept of crashing into one another did not pold any water with this viewer, but the reality we all deal with certainly did. Our cast is shown to cope with their own emotional versions of the truth, with heroic honor and self revelations.

title: emotional drama - intense topic.
review:
The successful and popular writer and producer Paul Haggis convinces with his second "Best Film"-Oscar-winning production "Crash" after "Million Dollar Baby". He implements the ethnic conflict in Los Angeles in an emotional action-packed film full of socio critical scenes. The viewer explores the racial attitudes and stereotypes which can not only be found in L.A., but also in most cities all over the world. Haggis has created a film which provocates to think about the conflicts everyone is involved in, but also is an intense criticism of the actual situation.

The action takes place in Los Angeles over a time lapse of one and a half days. The car-jacked couple, Rick Cabot (Brendan Fraser), the LA District attorney, and his wife Jean (Sandra Bullock), raises their stereotypical prejudice against others from different ethnic groups, for example their Latin house hold help or the Mexican-American locksmith Daniel Ruiz (Michael Pe√±a). The car-jackers Anthony (Ludacris) and Peter (Larenz Tate) experience a mind change and a tragical event based on a misunderstanding through the prejudice of Officer Tom Hansen (Ryan Phillipe), who first seems to be the person who trusts most in strangers without stereotypes and criticizes his partner Officer John Ryan (Matt Dilon) in his racial action. There are also Cameron Thayer (Terrence Howard) and Christine Thayer (Thandie Newton), who are flagged down by Officer Ryan for no cause; and the African-American police detective Det. Graham Waters (Don Cheadle), who is having an affair with his Latin partner Ria (Jennifer Esposito). All characters are bound to their personal development, they are forced to reassess their thinking and point of view against other ethnic groups.

Haggis has created a breath-taking film, which illustrates the conflict between ethnic groups very well. He also makes use of different cinematic devices to let the viewer witness the 36 hours development and identify with the characters opinions and thoughts. The viewer undergoes the process of the mind changing of the various characters, which are all elaborated very detailed and represented in all of their attitudes. Many emotional situations are existing as well as thrilling and pulsating moments. The created atmosphere according to the mind changes does also develop and electrifies the audience. The whole production forces the viewer to also change his mind, as the topic is still actual and biases and racial assumptions are occurring all over the world at this very moment.

In conclusion, Haggis created a very critical film, which deals with a very actual and intense topic. He shows the development of the different characters very well and detailed as well as the various stereotypical thinkings which are existing in everyone. "Crash" can only be recommended because of its extensive elaboration and the implementation of the still current topic: racism.

  • by Fabian Finke and Kevin Kreker -

title: Crash is a pretty crazy story
review: Several stories interweave during two days in Los Angeles involving a collection of inter-related characters, a police detective with a drugged out mother and a thieving younger brother, two car thieves who are constantly theorizing on society and race, the white district attorney and his irritated and pampered wife, a racist white veteran cop who disgusts his more idealistic younger partner, a successful Hollywood director and his wife who must deal with the racist cop, a Persian-immigrant father who buys a gun to protect his shop, a Hispanic locksmith and his young daughter who is afraid of bullets. The movie shows that people are born with good hearts, but they grow up and learn prejudices. Which, in turn bring out bigotry and racial stereotypes. The setting in Los Angeles, a city with a cultural mix of every nationality. The story begins when several people are involved in a multi-car accident. From that point, you are taken back to the day before the crash, seeing the lives of several characters, and the problems each encounters during that day. An LAPD cop (Matt Dillon) is trying to get medical help for his father, but he is having problems with a black HMO clerk who won't give his father permission to see another doctor. He in turn takes out his frustration on a black couple during a traffic stop. A socialite (Sandra Bullock) and District Attorney (Brandon Fraser) are carjacked at gunpoint by two black teenagers. Sandra takes out her anger on a Mexican locksmith who is changing the door locks to their home. Later that night, the locksmith is again robbed of his dignity by a Persian store-owner. Many of the characters switch from being bad-person-to-hero in ways. Farhad (The Persian) thinks Daniel (The Mexican) looted his store, so he grabs his gun and goes to Daniel's house. He threatens to shoot Daniel and Daniel's daughter runs outside to protect him because she has the invisible cape. She jumps into Daniel's arms and Farhad shoots her. It turns out that the bullets were blanks and the family goes inside and Farhad is left to think what he did. Peter and Anthony (Ludacris) try jacking Cameron's truck. Peter is left behind as Cameron and Anthony speed off. They are cornered by police. Cameron is finally fed up with the prejudice he sees and steps outside and tries to get shot. Officer Hanson recognizes Cameron and orders the officers to put down their guns and forces Cameron back into the truck. Cameron drops Anthony off. Peter tries to get a lift later and Officer Hanson picks him up. As they're driving, Peter notices the statue of St. Christopher that he carries along at starts to laugh. Thinking that Peter is laughing at him, Officer Hanson orders him out. As Peter goes to grab the statue, Hanson thinks it's a gun and shoots Peter. He sees what he was really reaching for and freaks out. He dumps his body at the side of the road and burns the car. We end with the beginning, where Det. Waters investigates the crime scene. We find out that in fact Peter was his brother. Anthony ends up riding the bus but gets out when he sees the Chinaman's truck, keys still in the lock. When he takes it to the chop shop, they find out there's a bunch of Asian immigrants in the back. Georgie offers 500 apiece for the immigrants and the money is excepted. The End :)

title: Moving at the speed of life, we are bound to collide with each other
review:
Crash is one of the best movies that I have ever seen. It is so powerful and very well executed. It is a film that I believe all individuals should take the time out to watch just once. This movie intertwines the lives of many unrelated people living together in the city of Los Angeles, California. It all takes place within a 36 hour time period. It focuses on the social and racial tensions that people face every day and it uncovers the negative truths of our shared humanity.

The cast of Crash is plentiful with big Hollywood stars:

¬ï A Brentwood housewife and her DA husband: Sandra Bullock as Jean and Brendan Fraser as Rick ¬ï Two police detectives who are also lovers: Don Cheadle as Graham and Jennifer Esposito as Ria ¬ï An African-American television director and his wife: Terrence Howard as Cameron and Thandie Newton as Christine ¬ï A Mexican locksmith: Michael Pena as Daniel ¬ï Two car-jackers: Chris "ludacris" Bridges as Anthony and Larenz Tate as Peter ¬ï A hardened cop partnered with a rookie cop: Matt Dillon as Officer Ryan and Ryan Phillippe as Officer Hansen

Life moves fast and this is something that all viewers can relate to. As citizens, we are often walking around in our 'own little worlds.' The theme of this film is to take a look at all the different walks of life and it allows us to see things from all points of view, not just our own. Our actions cause reactions. Too often people do not stop to think about how their proceedings will affect others. This film takes things to the extreme and it shows us the consequences that may result.

A tag line for this film is: We crash into each other just so that we can feel something. This is in relation to the fact that we are somewhat robotic in our daily lives. We have to work, some individuals even have to pick up second jobs, many of us are parents, and some of us are still furthering our educations. The hustle and bustle of daily life can cause us to slowly build resentments we are not even aware of. In addition to the theme of how we can affect others; there is also a piece of this film that shows how many of us are brought to our breaking points.

In some ways this movie did show similarities to the movie American History X. Crash is much broader. However, both of these films address the 'elephant in the room.' They cover topics that people do not like to talk about, but topics that are very real. They are both racially related. They both teach some sort of life lesson and show us things that truly make life meaningful: Love, family, the power of relationships, and respect for others.

There is phenomenal technique within the editing of this film. They weave together the lives of strangers and the transitions are extremely smooth. It can be hard when jumping from one unrelated scene to another and I give the editor of this film a lot of credit. Many of the scenes were filmed multi-camera. There was quite a bit of rearranging that had to be done and I found the editing to be flawless.

The sound effects and soundtrack are also very important elements used in this film. The end of this movie is quite a long 'aha moment.' The events all come full circle and everything that had been unpredictable throughout the film now makes perfect sense. Sounds help to heighten the intense moments in film. They have done an outstanding job here.

In summary, we live in a society where we must behave in a politically correct manner. But at the end of the day, we all see the world from our own perspectives. This is the reality. I found this film to be very real. As a viewer, I can really appreciate this. These are necessary issues to uncover. I feel as though these discoveries can only help us to become better people and better members of society. If I could, I would mail a copy to every household in the United States! This is a great film. I cannot say enough good things about it.

title: Over the Top but Fun Ride
review:
In the film "Crash", that is written and directed by Paul Haggis, several characters' lives crash into each other as they are dealing with racial tensions in LA. The long list of characters includes a white district attorney Rick Cabot (Brendan Fraser) and his wife Jean Cabot (Sandra Bullock) whose car is stolen by two black men Anthony (Chris "Ludacris" Bridges) and Peter Waters (Larenz Tate), a black TV producer Cameron Thayer (Terrence Howard) and his wife Christine Thayer (Thandie Newton) who are pulled over by two white cops Officer Ryan (Matt Dillon) and Officer Hansen (Ryan Phillippe) of which one is racist and inappropriately frisks the wife, a Hispanic locksmith Daniel (Michael Pena) and family, a Persian store owner Farhad (Shaun Toub) and his family, a Chinese couple Choi (Greg Joung Paik) and Kim Lee (Alexis Rhee), and black detective Graham Waters (Don Cheadle) and his Hispanic female partner Ria (Jennifer Esposito). Their lives become intertwined through car accidents, vandalism, and shootings and their attitudes toward each other change throughout these events.

The major of theme of racism is really blatant and in your face throughout the movie. I found this to be a bit unrealistic. It's not that I don't think there are that many racist people, but the way in which their stories are all connected takes away from the realism. However, as much as it was unrealistic, I didn't mind because of the ride that that the film takes you on. Some characters use race to have power over other people, and other characters seem to learn from the mistakes they have made regarding another's race.

The style of the film is amazing and keeps you on the edge of your seat throughout. With each scene, I was curious how it was going to bring us back to the beginning of the film. Its style is a reminder of Paul Thomas Anderson's "Magnolia" which also includes a large cast of characters that are interwoven together. It's a complex style, but the theme is simple so it is easy to follow. I would recommend this film for the ride it takes you on and the discussions it will lead to in the end. The film highlights a serious problem in our world, even if it is portrayed a bit over the top.

title: Follows a group of people and how they are connected through racism and violence
review:
This film focuses on a widely diverse group of people who seemingly have nothing to do with one another. Brought together by issues of racism and violence, their stories intertwine in the end showing how everyone's lives intersect somehow.

Starring Sandra Bullock, Brenden Fraser, Matt Dillon and Don Cheadle just to name a few, this award winning film gives the audience a brief look into the lives of a group of people who learn many different lessons on life. The major theme of the movie is clearly defined as racism. All of the characters in one way or another face some form of racism and all handle it in their own way. The secondary theme of the movie is violence; however the two go hand in hand. The racism is based on violence and the violence is based on racism.

The two major film techniques used in this movie to give it dramatic effect are camera angle and editing. Every scene in the movie is short, seemingly unorganized, a few moments of each storyline. The camera angles are important because they show the important aspects of every scene. They don't focus so much on the action but rather the human reaction and emotions of each character. In the end the unorganized scenes start intersecting and the audience sees the other characters in different story lines. This technique brought the film together in a way that helps you understand that everyone is connected be it personally or emotionally.

title: A movie that shows the unfortunate cruelty among the world and the harmful results that come from it
review: Crash is a movie directed by Paul Haggis about a handful of different characters all with a similar struggle that connects them to one another. The movie jumps from one story to another, not tying in how they are all connected until the end. Each character in the movie faces the issue of how to not only live among, but treat different racial and ethnic groups. Ryan Phillippe plays Officer Tom Hansen who attempts to fight the racial separation in the city of Los Angeles and more specifically his partner Officer John Ryan, played by Matt Dillon. Don Cheadle plays Det. Graham Waters, Terrence Howard plays Cameron Thayer, and Sandra Bullock plays Jean Cabbot. The acting is well done in the movie, Crash. The viewer is left feeling an emotional tie to each character. Whether the viewer is feeling hatred, hurt, or sorrow, each actor is able to tap into the emotions of the viewers. This movie is similar to Gran Torino. Both have themes that deal with the fight of racism and prejudice. In both movies, the characters don't know how to deal with the characters of other races. Then, as the movie goes, the characters come to realize that their race and heritage don't define them as people. The movie, Crash, uses different camera angles to intensify the film. The camera zooms in on character's reactions and certain important scenes. During intense action scenes the camera angle is farther away to give the audience a clear view. Then, when the characters are reacting to the recent occurrence, hurtful slur, or sad scene, the camera zooms in close. Also, the lighting is important. Some scenes are dark and relate to the dark attitudes the characters have towards one another. Many scenes are set during the night. The surrounding is dark, but the characters features are lit up to intensify their reactions and feelings. The lighting makes the viewer feel the darkness of the theme. The movie is all about the struggle of the different cultures living together in peace. It shows the hardships some of the characters face because of their race, religion, or heritage. Crash gives a brutally honest idea of how cruel people can be to one another. The ignorance and lack or compassion the different groups of people have towards one another in this movie is a big theme. This leads some characters to be cruel and hurt others. The movie proves time and time again that the stereotypes and ideas one group has towards another is generally wrong. Without the terrible assumptions and hurtful behavior the characters have towards one another, all of the accidents and tragedies could be avoided.

title: Racist Reality
review:
The movie Crash, directed by Paul Haggis, centers around several individual lives and their imminent fate that leads them to cross each other's paths in a web of racism and violence. This film features well known actress Sandra Bullock and A list actors such as Terrance Howard and Matt Dillon. Bullock plays Jean Cabot, wife of the District Attorney, who is carjacked by two black men which fuels her racist attitude. Dillon is a racist LAPD Officer John Ryan that acts inappropriately towards a black couple, Cameron Thayer (Terrance Howard) and his wife. The intertwining events come full circle when a car crash occurs and Thayer's wife's life is at risk.

The strongest and most prevalent theme is racism. Almost all the characters have strong feelings of disrespect and dislike towards someone of another race. The main players include Officer Ryan, Jean Cabot, and the Thayer couple. However, lesser characters also allow racism to be an underlying tone. This includes an Iraqi store owner distrusting of a Hispanic locksmith and a cop duo comprised of an African-American male and a Hispanic female. The language and actions of the characters clearly demonstrate their attitudes toward others unlike themselves. Until the end of the film, the racism is unrelenting. There are other films that share a similar theme which includes Babel, directed by Alejandro Gonzalez. The characters in this movie are also victims of fate and unfortunate circumstances.

Some of the techniques in this film include the camera angles and lighting. The issue of race is general a dark theme. Most of the scenes throughout this film are also dark. The carjacking occurs at night in the darkness as opposed to in the daytime, which illustrates the severity of the incident. While the camera angles are varied, there are several scenes with long intense lingers on the character's face. This moment allows the viewer to get in touch with that character's feelings of angst, disgust or hurt.

Overall, the film touches all of the areas surrounding race from different cultures. The fact that this movie occurs within a short time period and in the same city, further points out what many of us come into contact with each day. Although at times the content may be offensive and may make the viewer cringe, it is very poignant.

title: Multi layered drama
review: Crash confronts the racism that is within all of us, whether we admit it or not. It begins with Asian women screaming racial insults at each other at a traffic incident. Next up is Middle Eastern people in an argument at which a man buys a gun. The third scene is a car jacking of a white district attorney an his wife by two black men. The d.a.' s wife is later having the locks changed in their house when she makes racist remarks about the Latino locksmith. A pair of white police officers pull over a black husband and wife and frisk them aggressively, even to the point of sexual harassment of the wife. More examples of racial prejudice continue to a shattering conclusion. Paul Haggis does a good directing job with a fine ensemble cast.

title: Makes a great statement
review: Paul Haggis weaves a spellbinding tale of sadness and disrespect for people who don't know each other. Cultural differences and fear drive snooty Jean Cabot (Sandra Bullock) to demand her door locks be changed again in the morning as the Hispanic locksmith works within earshot on the Cabot's last door. The protective shell around Jean Cabot is her mansion of a home. Even her pretend friends don't come to her rescue. Six intertwined stories take place in Los Angeles, CA. involving police officers who become hardened (Matt Dillon), Persian store owners, a black detective struggling to keep his family together, an upper class, black movie director, and a pair of thugs who seem to be on the edge of knowing right from wrong. Excellent cinematography and suspense keep the film moving forward. Camera angles help separate the stories by pointing way up in the sky, or shooting down from a very high point. Costumes and vehicles make the characters very believable. The director's wife, Christine (Thandie Newton) is always seen in designer clothes and high heels. She seems to have a shell around her keeping her from really bonding with anyone, but trying to get closer to her husband. The actor (Ryan Phillippe) who plays office Tom Hansen, seems genuinely concerned about people. The shell around officer Hansen keeps him from bonding with other officers. As the new guy he still wants to give people a chance before pouncing on them like his partner does. Nice guy locksmith, Daniel (Michael Pena) gives his protective shell to his daughter who is afraid of bullets. The timing and editing in this movie is very different from any other movie I have seen. After seeing this movie and the outstanding performances of actors like Don Cheadle and Thandie Newton, you can't help but ask yourself what the world would be like if people would just deal with circumstances, help each other out, and completely disregard skin color.

title: An all time great movie! A well deserved Oscar!
review: You can watch this movie over and over again and never get tired of it. The acting is extraordinary, the topic and plot realistic and gut wrenching. The show is also one that envisions negative actions as having negative results, that is you reap what you sew or to put it another way, life is a circle and things come back around to bite or reward you. Further to this, one of the most profound lessons to learn from this movie is that we humans are a mixture of villain and hero. We have the ability to choose which we're going to be at any moment. Not many movies being made these days make any dent in our self indulged semi-conscious lives, but this show does. It makes you think and demands your full attention. Don't watch it with someone who never shuts up or has the mental capacity of an Amoeba. This is a movie to share and to discuss long after it's over.

title: The movie Crash is a story about human relationships.
review:
The movie Crash is a story about human relationships and how the lives of several people cross paths during the period of 24 hours. From the start, we have preconceived notions as to how people will react in certain situations and this holds true for a little while. However, with just one word, one action, situations are turned around and characters grow. Although some characters in the story change for the better, others' lives are forever scarred. This movie contains racism, stereotypes, and prejudice that we can relate to in our own lives.

Some of the characters in this movie include Brendan Fraser as Rick Cabot and Sandra Bullock as Jean Cabot, a white District Attorney and his wife; Don Cheadle as Detective Waters, a black detective whose brother is missing and whose mother is addicted to drugs; and Matt Dillon as Officer Ryan, a racist white police officer taking care of his sick father. Additional notable characters include two young black thieves, Ludicrous as Anthony and Larenz Tate as Peter Waters; a Latino man, Michael Pena as Daniel; an Iranian shop owner, Shaun Toub as Farhad; and a wealthy black TV producer and his wife, Terrence Howard as Cameron and Thandie Newton as Christine. There are several other characters who make an appearance during the course of this film.

The movie begins in the present but flashes back 24 hours in an attempt to bring us to the emotional state of the present. Like Richard Curtis' Love Actually, throughout the movie we jump from story to story and then back again, sometimes overlapping each other. This is done so we can watch the changes taking place within the characters as they "crash" into and relate to each other. In addition, the sounds of several crashes and gun shots as well as the use of black screens are utilized to invoke suspense and fear from the audience. As the film is viewed, the audience is pulled into all of the feelings the characters portray including rage, anger, fear, relief, sadness, and grief.

All of us have had to relate to at least some of the issues employed in this film. Whether it is dealing with someone who is angry, being involved in an accident, or being the victim of a crime, we get to follow the characters in this film as they move through and deal with their emotions. Each character is changed by the end of the film. Some characters find the biggest problem within themselves, others learn that there are just some things they cannot change, while yet others have a little help from others to help them see the light.

title: This movie displayed true concepts in every day life that not everyone is willing to accept
review: The movie Crash involves several stories that are interwoven and connected within a thirty six hour period, without the characters in the story line being unaware of how their actions and beliefs affect the other person or other people. The theme of this movie show how people of all races and classes are interconnected by their attitudes and beliefs that affect each other in a profound and life changing way; from racists attitudes and beliefs from their own personnel experiences in life to how they got where they are in life and why. The main character Detective Graham Waters (Don Cheadle) is an African American Detective with the Los Angeles Police Department, his girlfriend Ria is a Latino Police Detective (Jennifer Esposito). His mother (Beverly Todd) is a drug addicted woman who's only concern is her youngest son, Peter. Peter is constantly in trouble with the law and Detective Walters is constantly trying to help his mother and brother Peter to clean up their lives. Jean Cabot (Sandra Bullock) is the wife of a D.A. Rick Cabot (Brendan Fraser) who is too busy trying to get re-elected than to worry about the problems his wife is dealing with after getting car jack by two African American Males, Anthony and Peter. Jean deals with her racist attitudes and thoughts. Her husband is trying to bribe Detective Waters in order for the election to go in his favor. Anthony and Peter are always talking about racist's attitudes and the mindset of society as they continue their crime spree throughout the movie. Cameron Thayer (Terrence Howard) an African American Director and his wife Christine Thayer (Thandie Newton) are pulled over and harassed by a racist cop, Officer John Ryan (Matt Dillion) and his new partner, Officer Tom Hansen (Ryan Phillippe). Officer Ryan is dealing with his own personal problems with his ill father and his lack of adequate insurance coverage. Officer Tom Hansen is new to the police force and doesn't like the way Officer Ryan deals with people of other races, he wants to do the right thing but not sure how to make a stand. Officer Ryan does not believe he is racist and tries to help others, but ultimately proves his reactions to a situation that he is a product of the environment he is in; as we all are. Then the Persian immigrant store owner Farhad (Shaun Taub) and his daughter Dari. He buys a gun for protection of his store. He believes the Mexican lock smith did not fix his locks the way he should have. Farhad's daughter picks up a box of shells that are blanks because she is trying to control her father's irrational and racist behavior. The Mexican lock smith and his daughter who is afraid of the crime and violence that goes on around her. Her father tries to work hard and protect his daughter despite the racial prejudice he experiences We are all victims of our own beliefs, by what we have experienced in life or been taught. Crash combines many prejudice and racist thoughts and beliefs by its characters reactions to each other as they interact with life events. The climatic ending which starts at the beginning of the movie shows how we are all running through life with the ability to crash into each other but are able to put are hateful thoughts and feelings aside in the face of tragedy and human need.

title: Great movie which revolves around deep rooted conscious thinking about racism, and cultural prejudice
review:
Crash is a thought provoking movie based on a simple premise of following eight characters that represent people from all walks of life. Screenwriter and director Paul Haggis drama revolves around the racial tension and gender stereotypes of a group of strangers in Los Angeles. that is strung out on drugs, and a young thieving brother. Grahams partner Ria (Jennifer Esposito) is also his girlfriend. Jean(Sandra Bullock), the wife of Rick( Brendan Fraser) who is a district attorney in L.A., is highly uncomfortable around anyone unlike herself, and as proof of her personal conviction, her SUV was stolen by two African Americans-Anthony (Ludacris) and Peter(Larenz Tate). Christine, (Thandie Newton) the beautiful wife of Cameron(Terrence Howard), a well to do television producer are pulled over by police officer Ryan (Matt Dillion) who interrogates the couple and sexually harasses Christine while husband Cameron watches on. Cast members Loretts Devine, Ryan Phillipe, and Larenz Tate all give a great performance. The theme of the Crash touches on the exploration of other issues such as racism, cultural prejudice and how people tend to look at others a particular way based on assumptions learned through life. The movie showed how we all live in our own comfortable bubbles, and sometimes we don't think about relating to those of different backgrounds, and socio economic statuses. A great example of another movie that has a similar theme can be seen in the movie Driving Mrs. Daisy. Hoke, played by Morgan Freeman is the chauffeur to a wealthy old Jewish woman, Daisy Werthan, played by Jessica Tandy. The way Miss Daisy treated Hoke as though she did not want him around and accused him of stealing from her shows her mindset towards those of a different socio economic class, and racial background. It wasn't until much later on in life that Daisy realized that Hoke was a true friend from the beginning.

In Crash there was a particular scene where scene where Officer Ryan was called to an accident an had to help Christine out of an over turned navigator. The angle in which the scene was shown was upside down from Christine's point of view. The cameras angle and perspective the viewer was able to get a feel for what was happening psychologically to Christine. As the camera moved back and forth in angle, it was easy to see that Christine was clearly in a distraught state, and initially refused Ryan's help. Officer Ryan's previous meeting of Christine came when he pulled her over and sexually harassed her after he verbalized his dislike of her being in the car with a Black man to his partner. Christine's obvious dislike of Ryan is stemming from that previous incident. This type of racism and dislike was prevalent throughout. The lighting is allows used very creatively throughout the movie. The incident when Officer Randy pulled over a Christine and Cameron was done in the evening. The lighting was adjusted so that the audience could see the details of what was going on in the scene clearly, but dark enough to portray the mystery of the event taking place. In the beginning everyone lives in their own bubble and tend to look at those outside of their bubble as alien. Not realizing that we all are the same seems to be the major expulsion throughout the picture. Realizing to be careful how you treat others, because you never know when you are going to meet or need that person in the future. Crash uses racism and cultural prejudice in combination with synergistic fate as a way to draw and keep the audience attention, and what a great good they did.

title: Crash. I loved this film!
review:
Crash (2004). What an appropriate title for this movie. I loved watching this film. The storyline, character interactions, editing and direction were ingenious. I wanted to write a review without giving too much of the movie away, but found that hard to do once you start diving into the different directions this film takes. So not to take away the enjoyment of someone reading this post before watching the movie, I decided to focus this review on the theme, style, and techniques that the director/editor utilized in the film.

The theme of this film is centered on the style and structure of the film. This film incorporates many different characters and story lines that take place over the span of one day. Because of how each character intertwines with one another, the film was shot in a unique way. It gives the viewer the perception that while one event is happening in the movie, another is event is taking place at the same time.

The film incorporates what the film industry calls form cuts. This type of technique is often used to transition one scene into another by matching a similar shaped object to another shape in the next scene. For example, in the movie you will notice when Dorri (Bahar Soomekh) leaves the gun shop after the altercation between her father, Farhad (Shaun Toub) and the owner, she pushes the door of the shop to open. The scene then immediately jumps to (jump cut) to Anthony (Chris "Ludacris" Bridges) and Peter (Larenz Tate) pushing open a door of a restaurant to exit. The film incorporates more of these types of form cut transitions.

Another technique utilized quite effectively was the musical score to emphasize important scenes. One scene that the director/editor used to heighten the emotional mood of the film was the scene with Officer Ryan (Matt Dillon) and Christine (Thandie Newton). Both of these actors did a superb job in their roles. Officer Ryan is a bigot cop who had an altercation with Christine the night before by improperly performing a search on her. Ironically, it is Officer Ryan that comes to Christine's aid and saves her life from a car crash. The music in this scene is very powerful. There are very few lyrics, and the ones sung are not in English. The actions of the characters, facial expressions and the body language of the characters, helps heighten the score. There are number of things going on in this segment of the film and the music gives the viewer the sense that something is about to happen, and the film delivers on this buildup.

Crash is a great film and makes you think about all the stereotypes that we have perceived in our mind. A really good line from Officer Ryan was that you think you know who you are, but that you really have no clue." When looking at movie themes, it is sometimes determined if a movie has a universal interest. I definitely feel that Crash fits this evaluation because of the movie topics on prejudice, stereotypes, relationship conflicts, and human trafficking. All of these things are still issues all over different parts of the world today.

I highly recommend watching this film. If you saw the film Traffic (2000) by Steven Sodenbergh, than you will enjoy Crash. They both are shot in similar ways by intersecting multiple story lines and characters together. Officer Ryan's comment that I spoke on earlier also applies to Traffic. While watching this film you will begin to see people's character change, some for the good and some for the bad. Check out the movie and have fun watching for the form cuts and dramatic musical score that I discussed. Enjoy!

title: A world were racism and stereotyping exist no matter who you are.
review:
Crash Crash is a film exploring a multiracial cast and the lives they lead facing hatred and racism. Produced in 2004 and directed by Paul Haggis. This film has actress Julia Roberts playing Jean Cabot, Brenden Fraser playing Rick Cabot, and Matt Dillon as John Ryan. This movie demonstrates lives colliding and how we can all play an indirect role with each other.

This film reminds us that we should look at life with an open mind and not judge people by the color of their skin or where they came from. We may have preconceived notions about other races but we should treat everyone as their own and not judge an entire race from one person.

Jean Cabot demonstrates what racism is all about. She saw two black men walking in a nice neighborhood and immediately grabbed onto her husband. After the two black men realized what she thought, they high jacked the car that they were driving after holding them at gunpoint. When Jean arrived at her home the locks were being changed by a Mexican. By now she didn't trust anyone that wasn't white, so she loudly accused the Mexican of being a con artist and wanted the locks changed again. The Mexican heard her and left without saying a thing.

Another scene was when Officer John Ryan was trying to rescue a lady from a crashed vehicle. He had formerly threatened and molested her in front of her husband only because she was black. Officer Ryan thought he could do anything to anyone. Later after he realized he was rescuing her he felt remorse. He realized how uncomfortable he made that woman feel. All he knew is that he wouldn't give up on her now and wanted to earn her trust back. He rescued her and she was grateful for it. She hung onto him after he pulled her from the car and that showed that people are capable of getting over their differences.

After watching this film, you realize times don't change much. Even movies that are set in the present date still face racism. The Cider House Rules was another film that also contained racism and preconceived notions about black people. Although, it eventually came to a point where you just have to forget about the color of someone's skin and coexist with them because there isn't a real problem.

The movie was a constant reminder of people and their true feelings. When they pulled the camera in close you could really start to relate to these characters. Again, the scene where the officer was pulling the woman out of the car, was very well shot. You viewed the scene from within the car and it gave you a sense of what it was really like. It was dark, leaking gasoline, and you could see flames on the other car. When they pulled the officer out at first and left the woman, it showed his struggle and how he wanted to go back. That was one of my favorite scenes in the whole movie.

By watching this film a viewer should be reminded that no matter what color your skin is, you shouldn't judge someone else by an entire race of people. Don't let one person screw up your thought process for a whole race. Even though our world is crazy we must remember to not make it worse by feeding into hatred and racism.

title: The Domino Effect
review:
The film Crash (2004) is centered on a belief expressed by a detective (Don Cheadle) at the scene of investigation early on in the film. His idea is one that revolves around the notion that people, or strangers, used to touch and feel close to one another in the past. The detective expressed that as time and city life evolved the closeness that people once experienced and enjoyed had strayed away or had become forgotten. He continued by stating that this feeling is missed so much amongst the populace that these people will sometimes go to the extreme measures of crashing into one another just to experience it once again.

The film then flashes back to the day prior telling multiple stories that intertwine and lead to the scene that is being investigated by the detective. Differences in race, societal hierarchy, and privilege lead and guide the actions of these characters. Regardless of their actions or crashes into one another's lives, the characters progressively shape the story and ultimately play a key role in what happens in the end. This movie was a prime depiction of great editing. This film consists of telling many different stories which ultimately draw a connection into one another. Editing efforts ensure that viewers' ideas, links, and reactions are influenced and guided in a way that makes the film credible and logical. In the film there were many instances in which sound effects were used to contribute to the realism of the action in the film and the emotion actors were experiencing at particular times. One scene, involving a potentially fatal car fire, included sound effects which built upon the suspense of the scene. Translating emotion from the silver-screen to viewers came in the form of a repeated and melodramatic melody. The filmmaker made this continuously used the same melody which familiarized viewers and cued them to digest the actor's emotion. This film is about the influence, both directly and indirectly, we as humans have on the lives and people within our society; our individual beliefs, values, and actions impact those around us.

title: Crash is an outstanding film
review:
Crash deals with several real life stories that impact several characters in Los Angeles, California. Some main actors are Don Cheadle who plays Det. Waters, Matt Dillon who plays Officer Ryan, and Sandra Bullock who plays Jean Cabot. Racism and stereotypes are the major themes in Crash. These themes contributed to the film by showing how different races deal with each other in negative ways.

The storyline in Crash portrays a diversed group of people interacting in day to day activities that connect them together. Crash deals with how ethnic stereotypes are thriving in the minds and thoughts of people.

In one scene, two black teenagers are approaching Rick and Jean Cabot who are walking down the street. Jean notices them and immediately gets anxious or nervous. Although, they did carjack them, the point is that she was already afraid of them before they attacked them which shows how some white people are afraid of some black people.

In another scene, Officer Hanson gives Peter a ride in his car. During their conversation, Peter notices that Officer Hanson has the same figurine that he has. When he reaches in his pocket to show him, Officer Hanson panics, shots him and dumps his body in a field. This scene shows the fear that white people have regarding black people.

Gran Torino has a racism theme, as well. This movie stars Clint Eastwood as Walt who is very racist. He is upset that his neighborhood is becoming more integrated with Hmongs. This film shows how racism can deeply impact people in a negative manner. But, what is most enjoyable is seeing Walt demonstrate that people can change and become a positive factor in the lives of the people that he misunderstood early on.

The color and lighting was very realistic in Crash. During the daylight and evening scenes, everything looked very natural and had accurate lighting. For example, when Christine was in a car crash, the camera captured realistic lighting of the scene and the explosion.

Also, the angles really captured the expressions and demeanor of the actors. For example, in the main crash scene when Christine was stuck in her car, the angle of the camera captures the accident scene from each vantage point. This allows a realistic feeling that involves fear and anticipation, at the same time.

This film was accurate portrayal of how different groups of people feel about each other. However, their differences didn't keep them from crashing together in this dramatic film about racism and stereotypes. This film exposes the fears and prejudices that are engraved in our society and cultures. Some characters seemed to change the way they felt about other races as the films goes along, however, others still never changed their viewpoint.
