title: Provocative psychological drama
review:
THE STORY: Peoples of differing ethnicities and social-economic levels 'crash' into each other in Los Angeles over a two-day period. These people include:

  • A white cop who's angry over the downside of affirmative action and abuses his authority (Matt Dillon).


  • His young white partner who objects to the abuse and actively tries to counteract it (Ryan Phillipe).


  • A black TV director who feels emasculated over the racism he experiences and ultimately blows up (Terrence Howard).


  • His light-skinned wife who doesn't know when to shutteth up (Thandie Newton).


  • An Hispanic locksmith (Michael Pe√±a) and his young daughter with an 'invisible bullet-proof cloak.'


  • A Persian shopkeeper who needs a scapegoat after his store is horribly vandalized, not to mention his daughter and wife.


  • Two black car thieves (Ludacris and Larenz Tate), the latter the younger brother of a detective, Graham (Don Cheadle).


  • Graham's beautiful partner and bedmate, Ria (Jennifer Esposito), and her mother, a maid to...


  • The District Attorney (Brendan Fraser) and his wife (Sandra Bullock).


  • An Asian man who gets hospitalized and his frantic wife racing to see whether he's alive or dead.


"Crash" is reminiscent of another L.A. drama, the 1991 masterpiece "Grand Canyon," but has enough nuances to stand on its own. For one thing, "Crash" is even more serious and dark.

As you can see above, this is a very involved story with numerous interwoven story lines; it ain't no mindless popcorn 'blockbuster.' A casual viewing won't cut it. It's not that type of picture. Most of the negative criticisms about the film are by people who didn't watch closely and then lambaste the film with criticisms that aren't even legitimate.

For one thing, the film is about so much more than racism; it also addresses stereotypes, hypocrites, the capacity for good and bad in every human soul, second chances, passive correction and shame, self-sacrifice, redemption, forgiveness, abuse of power, the last straw, manhood & emasculation, giving someone a break, true friendship, misunderstandings, favoritism and more.

*** SPOILER ALERT ***

Furthermore, not every character is racist as some critics insist. Brendan Fraser's character never shows any racism and the only reason his wife (Bullock) blows up with racially-charged statements concerning the locksmith is because she just got robbed and shoved to the pavement at gunpoint by two young black guys. How would you or I react after such an experience? Also, Matt Dillon's cop partner never displays racism in the truest sense; why else would he radically come to the defense of the director who has a fit or pick up a young black male hitchhiking? (What happens later is a misunderstanding not real racism). What about the detectives Graham and Ria and Ria's housemaid mother? (Yes, Graham makes one derogatory statement about Hispanics, but that's it; he's hardly racist). These are all main characters.

Then there's the criticism that all the protagonists are "essentially one-dimensional racial stereotypes." This is completely untrue. Graham and Ria (black and Hispanic) are successful detectives; Cameron is a successful black TV director; and the Hispanic locksmith is a family-oriented working man, not a criminal or gangbanger. Yes, there are some people who fit the stereotypes, like the two young black male thieves and the racist/abusive white cop, but one of the thieves becomes shamed for his lifestyle & hypocrisy and the racist cop is willing to risk his life for a woman of color, thus redeeming himself (from the guilt he felt over abusing his power the night before), besides his white partner is anything but a white racist who abuses his authority. I could go on but this is enough.

One critic criticized the film with this multiple-choice question: "You are involved in a car accident on a busy street. The other driver is Asian. Do you:

a) Wait for the police to arrive and see if the other driver is okay. b) Exchange insurance information with the other driver. c) Scream and yell, "damn chinks don't know how to drive!"

"If you picked C, you'd love Crash."

This car-crash scenario DOES take place in the story, but he's leaving out some important details -- A woman & man are rear-ended by an Asian lady. Why don't they call the cops? Because they ARE cops and there are other cops on the scene. Why does the lady detective talk back to the Asian woman? Because the Asian woman is having a fit and throwing racial slurs (she's Hispanic). This is WHY she talks back to the Asian woman, not to mention she's a cop and therefore in a position of authority. Why does the Asian woman have a fit anyway? Because she's rushing to the hospital to see if her husband's alive or not. So, you see, the witty little multiple-choice question doesn't actually fit the reality of the film.

*** END SPOILER ***

Another criticism is that the racism in the story is not subtle like it is in real life. Well, haven't you ever seen anyone blow up like in the movie? I have. In a city as big as L.A. how many such blow ups happen over any 48-hour period?

Yes, there's a lot of raw emotion and hard-to-watch scenes, but there are undeniable glimpses of love, hope, redemption and forgiveness as well. If you're in the mood for a well-made psychological drama with numerous insights to the human condition, don't miss out on "Crash."

title: Is it genius? Is it crap?
review:
Crash seems to be one of the most polarizing Best Picture winners ever. A quick browse through the IMDb forums will show you that some people view this film as an ingenious masterpiece while others despise it with every fiber of their body. I find myself somewhere in the middle of these two opposing sides. There's a lot of debate over what Crash is, what it all means, and what its true motivations are. So much of this film is subjective and can be looked at in a positive or a negative light so I'll just establish fact. Crash is a movie about an ensemble of people whose lives intertwine over the course of two days in Los Angeles. We have a racist white cop, a high society black couple, a Persian family that owns a pawn shop in downtown, a black hoodlum who preaches about racism and avoiding stereotypes all the while jacking cars, a Hispanic locksmith, and various others. Over these two days these people learn about themselves through dramatic encounters that all fuel a motif of racism and stereotyping. This movie certainly has masterpiece potential, and maybe thats why I am weary to solidify my opinion on this film at this point.

In theory Crash is amazing. The thought going into the story is intelligible and complex. It's a story about finding out who we are and what makes us human. It seeks to examine the effects of stereotyping and where this kind of human nature leads us and how it makes us feel. If you examine the film closely you find all of these things in many different ways, but the issue comes from what you have to dig through to discover this metaphoric treasure trove.

Virtually every character in this film is a racist. And some of the racism is just so forced and is crammed down your throat in such a rude and unsettling way that you start to lose sight of the magic potential this film was heading towards. There are just certain moments where, try as you might, you just can't buy into the fact that some people are actually like that. I'm not denying that racism exists because it does and it is a sad part of our everyday life, but I just don't believe it at this level of force fed clich√©. Nearly every conversation in this film has to do with race and every bit of banter is racially motivated, so much so that it gets tiring and irritating to an extent.

Another place where I have some trouble connecting with this film is some of the characters. I said before, nearly every character in this film is racist and judgemental. The judgemental part goes back to the recurring themes of human nature but the racism is just too over the top for me to like any of these characters. Now I realized by the end of the film that the purpose of these unlikeable characters is that they are supposed to go through major revelations at the end of the film and learn who they are and where their own actions have led them. I know that at the end of the film they did all learn things, but I didn't feel like they learned anything. Obviously I saw it on screen. I saw Farhad part with his anger after almost killing a little girl. I saw Officer Ryan come to terms with himself and how his own bigotry was affecting his life. I saw Cameron realize who he was and that he still loved his wife in spite of everything. I saw all of these things, but I hardly felt any of them. There's a wall between me and the characters in this film that blocks all emotional connecting and this wall was built by the way in all these characters and their development were forcefully spoon fed to me.

But maybe Paul Haggis, director/writer of the film, is actually a genius for making Crash the way he did. Maybe he purposefully made the characters as blatant and clich√© as he did to frustrate and confuse people. And once they are angry they vent these feelings of frustration and start to boast why the film is wrong and why they are above this kind of clich√©d and predictable film. In doing so could they be proving Haggis' point about the people who think they are above racism and stereotypes? Are they just falling into another stereotype that Haggis actually addresses in Crash. We have the characters of Peter, Anthony's friend, and Officer Tom. These are the two characters who set themselves apart from all the racial tension and don't let it play a role in their lives. Of course, in the end, they are the most affected by it because of their own underlying stereotyping which they hadn't addressed in themselves until Tom shoots Peter. Are the haters of Crash just proving Haggis' point? This kind of meta filmmaking is a bit of a stretch, but one can never truly know, can they? I definitely have some issues with Crash, but it isn't necessarily a bad movie. However, its motives are too shrouded in subjective ambiguities for me to really connect with this film. I can see at least some of what it set out to accomplish, but the gray area is where much of the criticism, my own included, of this movie comes from. Of course as far as just pure filmmaking goes, Crash has a great cast and some powerful performances. Haggis' direction is also superb. Combined with the music it is even more powerful and dramatic and there are moments of this film where the visual quality is astounding and will not leave you. But when you take a long hard look at this film it is just really difficult to discern just what kind of a film Crash is.

title: A brilliantly crafted message that the title doesn't even hint to.
review:
Crash reminds me of a drama piece I did for an exam - an ensemble of different characters and events that seem separate but are related in theme and statement. Every performance in this film is excellent; every part no matter how small has been carefully thought out and acted with skill. All writing, acting and directing are fantastic, and special praise for the editing and the structure of the piece which always keeps you engaged and keeps the pace at the correct tempo.

Any problems I had with the film were probably just ones of taste; in terms of an artistic work, Crash is essentially perfect. It deals with racism in so many different and intelligent ways that, combined with great acting, give us a real sense of reality. However in the first 20- 30 Min's I felt like I was being bashed over the head with the message: RACISM IS BAD, with every character talking about race and discrimination which seemed unnatural to me. But that was most likely just to make it really clear to the audience what was being dealt with, and the narrative and dialogue settle after a while to deliver some truly amazing stuff.

Another gripe I had with this was that, as with my drama piece, it was very difficult to become emotionally attached to any of the characters as just as you get focused on one guy, it jumps to the next and you don't see the same characters on screen for another half an hour. Again, this was intentional - this film is to make us think, not feel; to reflect on our own attitudes and question ourselves what we would do in the same position.

A truly brilliant artwork, but it is in no sense a standard film as it's purpose is to convey a message through its story. It reminds me somewhat of Requiem For a Dream, in a good way, but without the emotional impact as we can't really connect with the characters too well. I shed a few tears at one bit though. In summary, it does exactly what its meant to do and any faults that can be found are merely due to discrepancy of taste.

8/10.

title: A movie which deepens our understanding about life!!
review:

its not a movie about the whites and blacks neither is it about good people and the bad, but rather it a movie which tells us to make a difference in the lives of other people. title: My 411th Review: Interweaving stories of race in modern LA
review:
I have seen Crash three times now and each time its Robert Altman approach improves - the way the stories interweave, the fact that it is addressing rather than disguising race, and the way the story impacts remains powerful and effective.

Many of the negative reviewers seems to find it akin to soap opera or like a Lifetime movie; I disagree, though it does resort to some clich√© in parts, the effect of the film rises above any simplistic notions of happy endings or trite messages, and tries to state and explore, nearly always with great success, the current state of race relations in the US.

Did Crash deserve its Oscar, is it the best film of the year? Perhaps not, but what it is, is a brave attempt through non-linear stories, to portray a very complex issue, in a way that has not been done often before in US cinema and for that reason alone its worth the award and worth viewing.

title: Outstanding movie

however as the movie progresses and you learn more about the characters you start to sympathise with them and thats the beauty of the movie.....judging a book by its cover is what the movie was made to do

The directors have done an outstanding job and its something you really need to watch to believe

i heard about this movie for ages and am glad i finally took the time to watch it....all i can say is....it really is that good

title: Uncomfortable truths of social relations in the "City of Angels"
review:
This movie commendably portrays the reality of social relations in one of the biggest and most important cities of the world: Los Angeles. Interwoven into this tale are the stories of several inter-related characters who are all portrayed to live quite separate lives,but still somehow come across each other in the course of their daily lives.

To start with, this movie quite effectively portrays the vile manifestations of anti-Muslim and anti-Arab racism in the months following the 9/11 attacks, where a Persian store-owner suffers a break- in and then breaks down mentally.

Cops are portrayed nonchalantly as racist and potential racist enforcers. Particularly interesting is the case of the young Officer Hansen played by Ryan Phillippe who initially is prone to non-racist attitude, but is instructed by his senior one time partner, played superbly by Matt Dillon, regarding the "realities" of being a cop. Hansen eventually succumbs to racist prejudice.

The film also includes a few people of the non-upper classes: two black youths who are led into crime and portrays a kind of catharsis for one of them when he is forced to go against his "principles" in a car holdup. Then there is the touching portrayal of a South American immigrant and his family. There is also the reality of human trafficking which is quite explicitly shown.

All in all, this is a movie which brings out many uncomfortable truths, in the midst of which the real sufferings of humanity in the midst of the so-called "City of Angels" stands out.

title: descent into relativism
review:
As an unfurled roll of 35mm film, "Crash" provides vignettes of disconnected, but intertwined, lives spiraling into individual discovery of the collective reality that surrounds them. Normally plying their lives within their individual frames, a number of people are forced to face personal fears, biases, and insecurities. The director skillfully brings what are totally disconnected relationships and the normal interaction of lives in the metropolis of Los Angeles into an examination of the realities of how closely those lives are connected ‚Äì and can often collide.

Too many to detail each person here, the main characters are intensely involved in their occupations and seek to overcome personal issues in the midst of internal and external struggle that fuels the issues even further. The thread within the film is a karma-like interconnectedness of these lives. In ways they will never know, each interaction provokes outward reaching ripples in the pond of each of the lives depicted here, causing them to search internally for answers. It brings to mind the story of the angry man coming home to yell at his wife, who yells at the kids, who yell at the dog, who barks at the cat, who jumps on the man ‚Äì clawing him.

In a culture once embedded with absolutes, ours is growing so relativistic that we are losing any point of reference for our actions. A quote that beautifully book-ended the film (along with the crash analogy) summed this succinctly: "Graham, I think we got rear ended. I think we spun around twice, and somewhere in there, one of us lost our frame of reference. And I'm going to look for it." It is apropos that, in that scene, the detective discovers that the brother he tried to protect by compromising his own ethics, is now dead. The sacrifice of his values was ultimately worthless . . . and saved no one ‚Äì including himself. This is a great picture to use in a discussion with this culture that is rapidly descending into relativism; the losing of ones' values leaves us with nothing.

title: Racial discrimination and its prejudice
review:
Crash (2004) is drama film produced, and directed by Paul Haggis. The film focuses on racial discrimination and its prejudice in California (Los Angeles). The movie relates several interwoven stories about different group of people and their dramatic scenarios: a black Hollywood TV director Cameron Thayer (Terrence Howard) and his wife Christine (Thandie Newton) who has to deal with a white racist officer John Ryan (Matt Dillon). John unsuccessfully try to get medical attention for his sick father from a black insurance representative staff Shanigua Johnson (Loretta Devine); a gang of two black teenager Peter Waters (Larenz Tale) and Anthony (Ludacris) carjacked, at gunpoint, the District Attorney Rick Cabot (Brandon Fraser) and his wife Jean (Sandra Bullock). Sandra takes out her anger on Daniel (Michael Pena), a Hispanic locksmith who is changing the door's locks to their house; an immigrant father who is discriminated by a shop's owner when he was buying a gun to protect his belonging. The movie theme refers to how racial conflict remains a subconscious matter that the mind can fail to control. The movie starts with Los Angeles detective, Graham Waters (Don Cheadle) who was investigating the crime scene where his partner and he were involved in a car accident. The accident and the crime were not connected. From there the film back up to the day before the incident. Throughout the movie, the sequence of events shifts between different characters; at the end of the film, characters switch from good to evil or vice-versa.

Officer John Ryan rescued Christine from her car accident. Before the incident, the same officer sexually molested her during a patrol. As opposed to his partner Tom Hansen who transferred to a one-man car to avoid his racist behavior, Tom ended up being involved in the murder of Graham Water's young brother (Peter). Jean changed her attitude towards her maid.. The camera angles in this movie were excellent; they make viewers feel as they are part of the action. Variety of sound is used from one scene to another to enhance the message the editor want the audience to get. From the opening scene to the final scene, the background music plays an important role. Haggis did a great job of telling the truth of how people can react when it came to racism. The use of music, sound links, dissolve transition, outside/in and inside out pattern, parallel cuts help to make Crash an excellent movie.

title: Crash is a socially compelling film where Paul Haggis's portrayal of cultural diversity and the communication is profoundly moving and frustrating.
review: Crash is a socially compelling film where Paul Haggis's portrayal of cultural diversity and the communication is profoundly moving and frustrating. It is masterful compilation of many different cultures and diversity that make it a, "Must See." It takes place in Los Angeles, first with an accident where Graham (Don Cheadle) who is an African-American detective reveals the symbolic meaning of "Crash". Soon after there is a situation, where a white racist cop (Matt Dillon) and partner (Ryan Phillippe) pull over a law abiding African-American couple (Thandie Newton and Terrence Howard) this wrongful assault leads to inappropriate actions that leave the un-expecting married couple in disarray. Then with a glimpse of Peter (Larenz Tate) and Anthony (Chris "Ludacris" Bridges), two black men walking down the street debating about the racial inequality that they experience, is when they decide to carjack a SUV that belongs to the District Attorney (Brendan Fraser)and his wife Jean (Sandra Bullock). This incident ignites a rage of racial terror in the district attorneys wife. Daniel (Michael Pena) is a quiet, polite Hispanic locksmith who is just trying to make a living for himself and his daughter and seems to be receiving racial aggression from everyone. First Jean when he has to change her locks, then a Persian family who loses everything in a store robbery that he had tried to prevent by replacing their locks and suggesting to the family they needed to replace the door. Graham (Don Cheadle) the African-American detective is looking for his lost little brother, when corruption rears it ugly head in the department. There are many different cultural situations taking place that brings out Haggis's theme for "Crash" and how it centers on communication between different races. The film displays how a mixed culture communicates and reacts with disrespect and ignorance, and immediately resorts to using hatred and violence as a way of communicating with their fellow man. This lack of respect and understanding usually ends with disastrous results. The setting adds to the films element of suspense because of the intense racial interaction and hatred that LA is riddled with. Using LA as the setting offers just the right mix to make the film feel real and alive. Crash is a montage of many different cultural backgrounds that balances out to generate a feeling of realism of what each of these people deal with on a day-to-day basis. Haggis uses many different technique of flash back and a crisscross structure to relay the feeling of the family's frustrations, anger and fears of how to effectively communicate and trust other cultures. He is able to show how most of the people involved in the film are not racist but have become a product of their unfortunate environment. Haggis is able to expertly juggle the extreme emotional effect with a sense of realism that keeps the viewer totally involved. "Crash" is not an easy film to accept, it brings to light many racial situations that are not accepted in society. With a theme, that centers itself around communication between different cultures in it ugliest form. However, it is wonderful production of realism and issues that many would like to think do not exist. This movie is a definite must see. I encourage everyone to view this film with an open mind.

title: Great movie that will stand the pass of time
review:
Who said that the Oscars movies can't be independent and good quality? Crash is an example of that.

A single event in somebody's life can have repercussions in many others. That is the point of departure of this post-modern holistic view of human interrelations and of modern American multicultural multiracial society. A portrait of the always bleeding American society and of the depths of human spirit.

Crash is a choral film in which each main character mini-story links to the others in an organic way. Moreover, is not a movie with good and bad people and roles, as all characters are deeply human, therefore, both shown in all its splendor and misery - sometimes disgusting, reproachable, racist and violent, some others heroic, tender, kind and good. The story has action and introspection at the same time, and the main characters are wonderfully drawn and played by all actors.

The movie, moreover, offers a raw unadorned image of American society and social groups - a society full of anger, violence and fear. Nobody is free from it - Rich or poor, immigrant or native, leftist or fascist, victims or executioners. But, again, the characters are not good or bad, are good and bad depending on the circumstances.

I loved the fact that some of the developments of the story made made me question assumptions and prejudices about people. In fact racist people can show non racist behavior and vice versa. Some people preach anti- racism and them behave in a racist way. Heroes can be villains and vice versa.

The director did a great job at creating unity and giving harmonic pace and sense to the emotional physical and cultural chaos in which most characters live. The movie makes you think, but it is entertaining and approachable, emotional and thinkable.

A great movie that will stand the pass of time.

title: A depiction of selfishness and altruism, or the eternal fight between Good and Evil
review:
OK, this movie covers the issue of racism and also about the American society, but there's something deeper in here.

You can see both mechanisms of survival in the human being: the instinct of survival of the individual (egoism) and the instinct of survival of the species (altruism). They both are present in every human being, and they are "transfered" from one human being to another in a "contagious" manner. When somebody is under the control of selfishness, he is virtually a hero for himself, and a killer for everybody else. There you have Cameron, a non-violent Buddhist man whose life you get to find caught under selfishness, with no fear to be killed by a gun, maybe even wishing to be shot as a sign of compassion for himself, who's willing to stop his suffering after other people "transfered" so many negative emotions to him that now that instinct is taking his life under control. And you can find that apparently hateful policeman, John Ryan, who abused a woman in the first minutes of the movie, saving later her life after a car accident, in this case, under the control of altruism, and acting as a hero, not for him, but for that woman. It's the perpetual fight of Good and Evil, depicted in a precise and understandable way. The policeman's father has a painful disease, and he transfers all his anger to his son day after day, who feels each day a little more helpless about a former compassionate person he truly loves. When we get to know that fact, we suddenly see him under a completely different point of view. The movie seems to tell us, "you see? it's just a matter of knowledge", and we even understand his madness: as spectators, we don't catch his anger any more. Fear, anger, desire, attachment. You can see all negative emotions which, according to Buddhism, cause suffering to humans, which in turn makes our ego grow and veils our minds. Other movies, like Star Wars, show that "force", and also how easy it is to fall into "the dark side", but no movie showed before, without metaphors, and with so much detail, how human nature works.

Suddenly, in the middle of madness, a combination of coincidences makes a miracle happen: a gun doesn't kill a little girl. That's a drop of Good which turns upside down a whole ocean of Evil, and shows that altruism, illusion, positive emotions... Good, in a nutshell, is our way to go, and also the strongest tool for survival provided by nature.

And this latter "miracle", and other scenes in the movie, like the one where Jean Cabot is angry and doesn't know why, and one minute later falls down the stairway, make me see this movie even in a deeper way. The Celestine Prophecy comes to my mind, with not just instincts involved, but the universal energy (something like "qi" from Eastern philosophies) flowing among humans in the form of positive and negative energy, and a superior ego controlling each of our lives in every detail as a master puppeteer. Within this framework, that miracle wasn't just a coincidence: it was one part of a kaleidoscopic reality where universal energy forces coincidences to happen. In other words, the little girl, with her innocence and true love, made that possible through a change in what we know as reality. This concept is very close to Buddhist karma.

Finally, this movie can also be interpreted from a scientific point of view in the form of the theory postulated by Richard Dawkins in his book "The Selfish Gene".

In any case, it serves as a hard criticism of the actual selfishness present in the American capitalist society, "preached" by Ayn Rand in her bestseller books, which have got to be almost as popular as the Bible, a line of thought that is spreading from the USA together with psychoanalysis to other countries like France and Argentina as a cancer in society. There are older movies which cover this issue in a metaphorical or allegorical way. One of my favorite ones is Invasion of the Body Snatchers (1956), remade in 1978.

Crash is a great movie, worthy of the Oscars it got. Watch out, there are two movies with this name in 2004.

title: Oscar makes expectations higher
review: The film is about ordinary people and important people's daily lives and strange coincidences between them, it's pure life actually and there's almost nothing which is not natural, (sorry, except the extreme behaviors of the iranian daddy), i watched the film in one gulp and did not get annoyed except the last 15 minutes which is too slow and predictable (same feeling like "no country for old men"), for me the music is so poor that it is one of the reasons for me why i did not give more than 7, its a good film, but music never supports the scenes and especially the final scenes are accompanied with a very simple random-radio song... and i think Oscar is a little bit too heavy, the film has not any action and almost all the scenes are in the same frequency, some poor music background and same kind of conversations, anyway, its a good film and worths watching once, probably you wouldn't want to watch it the second time as it does not have any hit scenes, or touchy quotes...or music.. watch it too see how ordinary life might be so complex around us...it'S pure life, but to see life on TV whereas you have the real one, is somewhat boring isn't it ?

title: Powerful and emotional film providing insight to racism today.
review:
Crash is directed by Paul Haggis. Crash has many large name actors/actresses such as Don Cheadle (Graham Walters), Matt Dillon (John Ryan), Sandra Bullock (Jean Cabot), Jennifer Esposito (Ria), Loretta Devine (Shaniqua Johnson), Ryan Phillipe (Tom Hansen), Larenz Tate (Peter Waters), Brendan Frasier (Rick Cabot), and Thandie Newton (Christine).

The entire film takes place in all of two days. Crash follows several people of different ethnicities. These characters include an African American director and his wife; a Middle East store owner and his daughter; two white police officers; an African American detective and his female Hispanic partner; a Latin locksmith and his young daughter; two African American teenage criminals; and a white district attorney and his wife. The film shows how these people experience racism and how they are also guilty of racism. All of these characters are connected by one "crash."

The district attorney and his wife experience a car-jacking (done by the two African American teens); then Jean is uncomfortable having a Latino locksmith change the locks in her home. The movie director and his wife get pulled over by two white cops; one of the white cops violates the wife and she gets angry at her husband for not standing up for her. The Latino locksmith is trying his best to raise his young daughter and provides her with a cloak to protect her from gunshots. This film shows raw racism. It is very real in that situations like these do occur on a daily basis even in today's society. Crash takes the viewer on an emotional roller-coaster. There are lots of negative attitudes depicted throughout the entire film. For example, Daniel (the Latino locksmith) changes the locks at the Middle Eastern man's store after it has been broken into. Daniel informs the store owner that he needs a new door but the owner refuses. He experiences another break-in and blames the locksmith. He goes to shoot Daniel and "hits" his daughter. It is then that the store owner discovers there were only blanks in the gun and thankfully the girl is okay.

Sound effects are important in this film. Silence is used in many of the crime and action scenes. Music also plays a vital role in giving the emotional effect. The variety of music played relates to the scene and conversations. Some music used includes: hip-hop, country, Middle East music, and Latin music.

Another film that exhibits racism is Gran Torino. However, in this film it shows one racist person (Walt). He is racist against everyone. Others in this film are accepting of Walt despite his racist ways.

Crash shows that everyone is different but yet we all have so much in common. It is tragic that racist situations still occur so frequently. This could easily be prevented if we all just look past our differences and see how alike we all really are.

title: We affect each other
review:
This fast paced, thought provoking film may very well change the way you see the strangers you encounter on a daily basis. Directed by Paul Haggis and starring Don Cheadle, Sandra Bullock, Ludicrous, Brendan Fraser, Matt Dillon, Ryan Phillipe, Michael Pe√±a, Shaun Toub, Cameron Thayer, Thandie Newton and many other wonderful actors, Crash (2004), gives you a glimpse into the lives of a district attorney and his wife; a cop who knows he's racist and one who believes he is not; a Latino locksmith and his young daughter; a black detective, his Puerto Rican partner/lover, and his drug addicted mother; a film director and his wife; a high strung Asian woman and her seemingly unlucky husband; two philosophical young black men who steal cars; and a Persian shopkeeper, his wife, and his daughter.

Over a twenty-four hour period you learn how these eight sets of otherwise unconnected people move in and out of each other's lives, altering the course of them for better or worse. The movie boldly addresses racial and social stereotypes‚Äîat times upholding them‚Äîbut usually contradicting them. More importantly however, the film focuses on how as human beings we may have our differences, but we are much more alike than we are different.

Not since The Breakfast Club (Hughes, 1985) have I seen a film so thoroughly remove the prejudiced lens through which we view others. We are all connected, and we all affect each other, whether we realize it or not. The movie progresses quickly and is never boring. It is full of surprises and keeps you guessing throughout. At times funny and at times poignant, I both laughed and cried during parts of this film.

Everything about this film is good; the acting, the cinematography, the soundtrack, and the unfolding of events. I highly recommend it to anyone who hasn't yet seen it. I actually watched it twice so that I could experience it with someone else who I knew would enjoy it. I seldom watch a movie twice.

title: Good flick
review:
Crash, written and directed by Paul Haggis, is a story concentrating on 8 seemingly unrelated characters whose lives "crash" down over a fateful 24 hours. With a star-studded cast leading the way, the film takes a hard look at the external tensions and stereotypes of the people in greater Los Angeles, and contrasts them with the internal struggles of the dealing with life in cultural melting pot. Reminiscent of Magnolia (1999) or Traffic (2000), each individual character's story is shown, and then woven together through various incidents that might seem like a normal day on the streets of L.A.

Sandra Bullock, Don Cheadle, Matt Dillon, Ryan Phillippe, Larenz Tate, and Terrence Howard lead a strong cast that give a deep introspective into the conflicts of life in L.A. Each main character has some stereotype, usually racial, that they are playing into, willingly or not. Dillon plays an angry LAPD officer that abuses his power, but at the same time shows a softer side while trying to take care of his sick father. Phillippe plays the opposite of Dillon, an officer who bucks the system and stands up for what he believes is right. He too is conflicted between his external values and the stereotypes of the world he lives in. This internal/external conflict is a constant theme between the other characters, from the upstanding district attorney's wife (Bullock) to the successful African American director (Howard) to the petty criminal (Tate). All of these conflicts come to a head in the 24 hours where their lives intersect.

Racial tensions play a key component in the story. The plot lines are controversial and attack real issues that affect our society head-on. The characters show the worst and the best of people, and take you on an emotional roller coaster as you learn more about them and what makes them who they are.

The subjective viewpoints throughout the film give the viewer the experience of living in these character's shoes. The cinematography and editing are top notch, and place the viewer within the correct frame of mind to understand the situation without being too obvious. The scenes, although seemingly disjointed and non-related, flow together into a wonderful series of stories. The strong soundtrack plays a huge part in this film, with subtle background music that highlights the seriousness of certain scenes, and the lack of any sound highlighting tense moments.

Crash brings good directing, writing, and acting together to tackle a difficult subject matter, and turns it into a great drama that tugs at emotions of the viewer throughout.

title: Spoilers The movie crash takes place in Los Angeles; this drama was written and produced by Paul Higgins.
review:
The movie crash takes place in Los Angeles; this drama was written and produced by Paul Higgins. This movie is about racism, conflict and the ability to change. This movie was inspired by a real incident when Paul got his porch stolen. The characters in this film made many mistakes toward each other in which affected them in the end. The main characters of this film are Sandra Bullock as Jean, Matt Dillon as officer John Ryan, Ludicrous as Anthony, Brendan Frasier as Rick, and Thandie Newton as Christine. Each of these characters played a major role in this film.

Jean, an upper class, middle aged white women, was having dinner with her husband Rick. When they were heading to their car, they got car jacked by two black men (Anthony and Peter) by gun. When she returned home a Mexican was changing their locks and she insisted on them being changed again in the morning because "He was going to sell them to his homies" . Rick told her that she was over reacting and insisted she go to bed. Come to find out later, he was a family man and had no relations with any sort of gangs. After the carjacking she really started showing her racist tendencies. When she slips and falls down the stairs no one would answer the phone, she then realized that her only true friend was a minority.

Officer John Ryan works for the LAPD, he notices a car that looked like the one jacked previously. His partner informs him that the plates don't match but John notices two black people were driving and proceeds to pull them over. He makes them get out of the car and while searching the man's wife Christine he molests her. He gives the couple the option to apologize for their "wrong doing" or go for a ride in the police car. Christine's husband apologizes and Ryan sends them off with a warning.

Christine is very upset with her husband for humiliating her and they get into a fight. She tries to make amends with him and he just under minds her. After leaving upset she gets into a horrid accident where she was stuck in her seat belt and the car is leaking gas. The only officer on scene is John Ryan, Christine then makes the decision to let Chris touch her and cut off the seat belt in which he saves her live.

The way this film was shot kept everything flowing very well. It starts with each character as an individual and ends with how every individual affected one another by their actions. I have only really ever seen two racist movies, Crash and American History X. These films are related in many ways. I think these types of movies show how people can actually change their perspective on life but it usually involves life threatening acts. But it is always good to know that people can change for the better. I enjoyed watching these movies because of the emotional affect that it brings.

title: The theme is centered on racism and stereotypes
review:
The movie crash involves a collection of events that bring multicultural characters together during an unforeseen situation. Each character is a victim of their own cultural bias that keeps them from interacting with others. In the movie stereotypes are challenged, confirmed, and cross-examined by the characters point of view . The film involves many actors that are connected by a single crash. The main character includes:

Jean Cabot (Sandra Bullock) Graham Waters (Don Cheadle) Matt Dillon (John Ryan ) Terrence Howard(Cameron Thayer) and Thandie Newton (Christine Thayer)

The theme is centered on racism and stereotypes. It explores how racial discrimination distorts our views and plays a vital role in the way we perceive and treat others. The irony in the film involves the characters no one knows who they will encounter in terms of tragedy and emotional anguish. Jean Cabot (Sandra Bullock) is a wealthy house wife her life is forever changed when she is robbed by two black men. She is now intolerant of people of color. Personal prejudices are formed from experience; those of us who had a bad experience with another race tend to stereotype that particular race. Graham Waters (Don Cheadle) is a African American detective with the LAPD. His negative view of his own race caused him to distance himself. Matt Dillon (Ryan) is a racist veteran cop who pulls over an African American married couple Terrence Howard (Cameron Thayer) and Thandie Newton (Christine Thayer). During this routine traffic stop Officer Ryan takes pride in degrading Cameron and abusing his wife. Powerless Cameron watch in agony as his wife is being humiliated. This incident of indecency put a strain on their relationship causing friction between the two.

Crash is a film that provides insight into people attitudes and behaviors brought on by bigotry and stereotyping races. The characters in this film are noticeably recognizable by their stereotypical behavior. Because the film is conflict motivated characters are too quick to use offensive racial remarks without merit. The scene takes place in the racially disjointed city of LA. Every day people pass each other by as if others aren't visible. The lighting of the film is symbolic to the headlights of a car that blur the vision of passing cars. Crash suggests our view of each other is distorted. The motif relates to the actual crash as it detailed how apparently unconnected lives overlap in entirely unpredicted ways. If it wasn't for the car crash the characters wouldn't be inter connected and forced to put their personal prejudices and side to help one another.

One of the main characters Don Cheadle set the tone for the movie; he states "We crash into each other, just so we can feel something." This comment suggests that we are unaware of own being and must try to connect with those around us. Our opinions of other are guided by notion that we are superior. Racism is learned behaviors that can be overcome if we take the time understand and value other cultures.

title: Good Movie. Worth Seeing.
review: Crash takes you through a two day in the lives of multiple characters in a way which shows different stereotypical and racist views that each character has towards another. Their lives are intertwined in a way that makes each question and possibly change their viewpoint towards another ethnic group. The movie stars Don Cheadle (Detective Graham Waters), Matt Dillon (Officer John Ryan), Ryan Phillippe (Officer Tom Hansen), and Sandra Bullock (Jean Cabot). In each "Crash" moment a character learns something about themselves and how they would react in a given situation. The movie is set in the City of Los Angeles and places each character in situations that are familiar to the area. Because of the racial tensions that have taken place in the Los Angeles area, it is a perfect setting for a movie that deals with stereotypes and racial diversity. The movie places each character into a racially driven predicament, and allows you to see how each responds. The setting of Los Angeles allows this to be believable due to the diversity of the area and allows the viewer to have an understanding of what life is like in the city. The lighting and filming techniques of Crash put the viewer into what the situation would be like if you were in it yourself. The director utilizes natural lighting to put you right into the view that the person in the scene they were really faced with that dilemma. The use of subjective and objective filming techniques helps to paint a picture for the viewer. In the objectively filmed scenes, you are allowed to see the environment and put it into its proper context. As you are thrown into the subjective view, you get the feeling of the drama that the character is experiencing and thus are given a rush of emotion that makes you, the viewer; feel as though you are in the scene. Like American History X, the theme of the movie is racially toned and shows similar stereotypes that people may view towards other races. Crash takes you through all the emotions that you may feel if placed in similar situations, but unlike American History X you are left wondering how you would respond if placed in a "Crash" situation. Will you have the same responses as the characters in the movie or would you respond differently. The only way to know is to be put into your own "Crash" and see what you would do.

title: A film that depicts racial overtones in our society
review:
The film combines several stories about issues of race involving several characters who live in Los Angeles. The theme of this film is racism and stereotypes about different groups of people. The film contributed to this theme by portraying how white people are afraid of black people. This film depicts characters in Crash within the context of many typical ethnic stereotypes that exist in our society today. For example, that Latino character with a shaved head and tattoos is a gang banger, an upper-class white woman who is discomforted by the sight of two young Black kids is a racist, two young Black kids as being criminals, but these story lines causes these characters to rethink their own feelings and beliefs during their "crash moment" when they realize what really exists within themselves.

Don Cheadle plays Detective Graham who is a black detective who has a younger brother that is a small time criminal and their mother cares more about the younger brother which bothers him. The Cabots are a white couple played by Sandra Bullock who plays Jean Cabot the wife of Rick Cabot who is played by Brendan Fraser. Rick is a district attorney and Jean has a strong dislike for groups of people other than herself. Chris Bridges plays Anthony who is a young black man who doesn't like white people. Larenz Tate plays Peter who is a young black man who seems to be more open to other races.

The Thayers are a black couple who are very successful played by Terrence Howard who plays Cameron and Thandie Newton who plays his wife Christine. This couple is confronted by Officer Ryan, played by Matt Dillion, a white cop subjects them to a humiliating, questioning and an inappropriate body search of Christine, while his new partner, another white cop played by Ryan Phillippe watches. And, Shaun Toub plays Farhad who is a Middle Eastern store owner who feels threatened because of the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks who decides to purchase a gun for protection.

Another film with a racial theme is Gran Torino. This film addresses racism and the negative effects it can have. Also, it demonstrates that when faced with the realities of beliefs and viewpoints, people can change.

The color and angle of the film were great. For example, when Christine was involved in a car accident and was pinned in her car. The camera was able to capture all of the angles of the accident. The color of the fire was realistic and the natural lighting in that scene enhanced the fear that was lingering.

These characters emotionally and physically collide in this dramatic film. Their lives avoidably connect and their prejudices and biases are exposed. Some of them learn from their racial experiences while others find out about their dark side.

title: Many different lives accidentally connecting
review:
Film Review: Crash ‚Äì 2004 Crash is a movie about people who live completely different lives and end up crossing paths with each other. Each person is guilty of racism in some type of way and they are all personally affected, changed, damaged, or victimized by this racism. Each character is made up of many layers which does not allow you to figure out exactly who that person is and how they will come out at the end of the film. The following are names of the major actors and actresses who make up this outstanding film cast:

Sandra Bullock as Jean Cabot

Matt Dillon as Officer John Ryan

Don Cheadle as Detective Graham Waters

Brendan Fraser as Rick Cabot

Terrance Howard as Cameron Thayer

Ludicrous as Anthony

Thandie Newton as Christine Thayer

Ryan Phillippe as Officer Tom Hansen

Larenz Tate as Peter Waters

Jennifer Esposito as Ria The theme of this movie is prejudice, racism, and stereotypes. It shows individuals, family members, business people, working people, and strangers saying the most hurtful and cruel things to one another. Every character in the movie has their own situation or irony facing a range of prejudice, such as, gender, class, and, race. In one scene of the movie, an Asian woman and Ria, a Latina detective, get into a car accident with one another and the Asian woman blames Ria for causing the accident and makes a comment about Mexicans not knowing how to drive. The Latina woman makes a comment back to the Asian woman about her being too short to see over the steering wheel and that she was the reason that the accident happened. This is one example of how stereotyping is used in the film. A scene that gives an example of racism would be when two black men, Anthony and Peter, are walking in the middle of downtown Los Angeles talking about white people getting better service than black people. Anthony commented on a black waitress only wanting to serve white people because she assumed that black people don't tip. Ironically, Anthony ended up not tipping the waitress because he said she gave him bad service. This film's theme is similar to the theme in American History X because both films give examples of racism, stereotypes, and prejudices. Each film shows the harsh reality of how ignorant people can be and how badly people can treat each other. Two techniques that worked really well with the theme of this film were the lighting and sound effects. Low-level lighting was used in the scenes where characters were plotting crimes and in scenes of sadness and misery. High-level lighting was used in the action scenes or rich people scenes. Sharpness, high gloss, contrasting colors, and shiny objects in the background are used for demonstrating situations where the characters are wealthy and their surroundings are supposed to look perfect. The sound effects for this film that were extremely appropriate were the noisy, city sounds of Los Angeles and the sound of silence. Each one gave a dramatic effect and made you feel as though you were involved in every storyline of the movie.

title: Movie about racial tensions
review:
My movie for this week was the movie "Crash", and it is a movie based on the social prejudices and stereotypes of today's society. The racial tension that this movie brings to light is not only sad, but at the same time, honestly portrayed because these very scenarios in this movie are everyday real life situations quite frankly. A few of the major characters are Rick and Jean Cabot, which are played by Brenden Fraser and Sandra Bullock. They are walking down the street about to get into their car when they are robbed at gunpoint by two black guys, and this act only confirms Jean Cabot's suspicions about young blacks in that neighborhood must be looking for trouble. Other characters were Cameron Thayer and his wife Christine Thayer, played by Terrance Howard and Thandie Newton respectively. Here's another type of racial profiling because Cameron was a well off movie director with money, and he and his wife are harassed by two white L.A.P.D officers just because they were black. Matt Dillion played one of the racist cops, and he was sort of dealing with his own prejudices against the system so to speak because of the lack of help he felt was not there to assist him with his ailing father. Chris "Ludacris" Bridges plays the role of Anthony, and his excuse for everything that's wrong in a black man's life is directly the fault of the white-man. Instead of doing away with all his excuses and taking responsibility for his actions, he'd rather steal cars from white people and continue thinking the way he does. The lighting is appropriate in this movie, especially on the scene when the Persian father was about to shoot the Mexican locksmith, and his daughter ran out in front of the gun shots. The scene went into slow motion and the lighting got hazy, emphasizing the magnitude of that moment. The camera angle was an important factor in the scene where Christine Thayer's vehicle had flipped, and she was stuck inside. The trail of gasoline from her car to other car was vividly shown by the angle of the camera, and it further added to the urgency for police to free her from the car and almost certain death.

The movie "Crash" forces viewers to acknowledge more than just the typical black and white problems of racism. But this movie opens it up to the rich verses the poor issues of racism, the post-911 issues of racism that mostly all Middle Eastern people had to deal with probably, and the issues of racism within one's own race about how one should conduct themselves given certain dramatic situations.

title: A study on the prejudices of a parochial world view
review:
A great number of people seem to focus on the racial elements of this movie, which is unsurprising because its so overt. However, there is a deeper element to this film which I found to be quite insightful.

Simply put, all people see the world through their own eyes and every single one of us instinctively feels that our view is the correct - or at least justified - view. What this film shows is how those parochially held world views, and the prejudices they create, eventually collide with reality.

It's a good film and there's more to it than a superficial portrayal of racial bigotry. One just needs to dig a little deeper...

title: Truthful, honest and admirably entertaining film-making which takes risks
review: I must insist that the thoughts I record when writing my reviews for IMDb are all my own, but before starting a review, I almost always read several others. I always include reading those by Roger Ebert (who, believe it or not, can drop some terrible clangers as to the detail of films ‚Äî I first noticed this in his reviews of Unforgiven and A Chorus Line ‚Äî which do rather shake your confidence in his judgment); and The Guardian here in Britain as well as those enthusiastic IMDb members who, like me, like to add our two ha'porth worth. Among the members' reviews there are invariably those which go to extremes and laud this or that film as quite possibly the best film ever made (presumably until they write their next review), and those that insist that this or that film is just so bad, it should be put out for cat litter. I find it difficult to take either of those kinds of reviews seriously. But Crash is one such film which arouses extreme emotions. As for the external reviewers, Ebert liked it (I think ‚Äî it's not always were clear what he thinks) but one of the reviewers for the Guardian was lukewarm. His criticisms can be summed up as 'liberals being self-consciously 'edgily' un-PC' ‚Äî he suspects that in various pitches to drum up support for the film, the fact that its treatment of race is 'edgy' was much to the forefront. Admittedly, the acknowledged aim of writer/director Paul Haggis was to make us, the viewers, aware that racism is everywhere and even in ourselves if we care to look closely enough, and in the Guardian reviewer's view that is about as original as announcing that water is wet. Yet on this occasion the chap is being too harsh. The 'message' of Crash is, perhaps, not quite as earth-shattering as Haggis would have us believe, but if, just for the moment, one can put the 'message' to one side, he and his producers deserve a great deal of credit for the film he made. It is never, ever dull and at times is immensely gripping. OK, there might, or might not, be some truth in the charge that Haggis's array of characters do tend to the stereotype, but from the six years I worked as a newspaper reporter I know that, without exception, each and every one of us can tend to stereotype if viewed from a distance. It is only when others get to know us better that our individuality emerges, but even then ‚Äî well, the news isn't always great. How often have we got to know someone better and discovered traits which weren't at all to our liking? Crash stands out in that there are no heroes or villains, no good guys and bad guys, merely people with their several flaws. It is very refreshing to watch a film such as Crash. It is a truthful. There is none of that posturing to effect all to common in modern cinema, and the characters shown in Crash behave as, in my experience, people do. At no point did it sound a false note. As for the sheer and admittedly huge coincidence of everyone coming into contact with everyone else, well, that didn't bother me a jot. Do we complain that Twelfth Night is unrealistic in that it is highly unlikely a woman could successfully masquerade as a man so well that another woman falls in love with her believing her to be a man? And although it would be presumptious to compare Paul Haggis to William Shakespeare they have in common that they are creating, or attempting to create, works of art. As far as I am concerned the essence of art, whether it be pure sound, paint on canvas, hewn stone, a film, a novel or a performance by an actor is manipulation and at the end of the day the only thing that counts is whether the creator of that work of art carries it off. And most certainly Haggis does carry it off. At no point does the level of coincidence jar. Overall, Crash is a one-off and a very successful one-off at that. If you like good cinema, do yourself a favour and give it a whirl. You really will not regret it. There is not a bad performance in it.

title: Do not judge anyone by the color of their skin or their background.
review: The plot of "Crash" is a group of people are connected in one way or another in a 24 hour period in LA. Connected being by way of family, relationships, hate, love, or by pure coincides. Mayor actors/actresses that appear in this movie are; Don Cheadle (Det. Graham Waters), Sandra Bullock (Jean Cabot), Matt Dillion (Officer John Ryan), Jennifer Esposito (Ria), and Karina Arroyava (Elizabeth). The theme of this film is prevalent throughout the movie, wanting the viewers to know that there is good and bad in every human being, and also not to judge people you don't know by the color of their skin or the normal stereotype they represent. Two techniques that I found really appealing in the film were irony and use of title to represent the meaning of the movie. I thought "Crash" was an extremely appropriate title for the movie. At the very beginning of the movie, one of the main characters, Graham Waters who is a detective is telling his partner, (which later you find out he has intimate relations with) "no one in LA touches each other." He then says, "Everyone lives behind a wall of metal and glass; I think we crash into each other just to feel something." The entire movie is about how people are so judgmental towards each other and have such strong racial hatred towards others. That is the only feeling they know and the only way they can crash into each other is by hatred. The irony in this movie also represents great emotion and understanding of the characters. One scene that really sticks out to mean where I was totally hung on the irony was when a young Mexican father tells his daughter this bedtime story one night after work when she is think she hears a gun shot in the neighborhood. He gives her an imaginary cape that will protect her that he got from a fairy when he was younger. She totally believes the story and has her daddy put the cape over her shoulders and she falls asleep. At the end of the movie, a man comes to the family's house to kill the father because he thinks he broke into his store. The little girl sees her dad outside talking to the man with the gun and she tells her mom that her dad doesn't have the cape and he isn't safe. She then takes off outside just as the man shoots the gun, the little girl jumps into her dads arms and ironically the bullets doesn't hit the girl or the dad. Everyone is amazed and can't believe what just happened. The man with the gun later on tells his daughter, that the little girl was his angel. This was a really good movie, and I really recommend "Crash" if you're looking for an emotion film that really has a message of not judging anyone by the color of their skin or their background.

title: There Is Nothing New Here
review: Some of the acting is pretty good, but the intent of the film seems a bit loose. If the intent is to show we all have prejudice, it succeeds on some level. If the intent is to show we all are capable of good and bad, it doesn't quite make it. If the intent is to show that all races in megacultural societies try, it's not realistic. What it doesn't show is that people operate most comfortably in their own culture with like people. This is not necessarily racially motivated--more, financially/socially. This is a truth. The dialogue is a bit stereotypic;it is someone else's version of how we speak. Again, mostly it is socially/economically oriented. The wealthy people are afraid of being robbed; the poor people feel abused and used. As long as America and like countries follow fascistic and republican tracks, this will never change. It is basically a have/have not society where people rarely cross over social barriers except through notoriety or fame. The rest of us are slotted by birth, family, education, etc. The lie is that America works. It is just another version of pre-revolutionary France. In order to be president of anything, you must have the backing and it is financial. You must cooperate with industry. Industry and banks run the nation. Politicians, Hollywood, and Madison Ave. are advertising puppets. It is about conformity.The rest of us have to deal with the anger and disappointment in the streets. The rich take cabs and have doormen. You are not immune unless you have a house in Dubai. What else have we got but who we are and what else to do than blame each other for our problems? I have to live with crazies, hoods and sickos in a city trying to lure wealthy Euros while it lets its infrastructure fall apart. I take the subway with messed up teens and street people who want to push anyone around because it makes their impotence less real. How do you fix that? I wait in long lines for everything and pay more than suburbanites for it. How do you fix that? I tolerate as best I can foreigners who ignorantly think they can impose their culture on ours because those who come here have money. This, after all, is the America they've been told has to tolerate everything and protect everyone! This is impossible. America is impossible. The freedom of all means nobody is free and nobody is represented. It makes lobal warming appear to be a blessing.

title: Slightly incomplete but pretty good
review:
Crash is not a great movie, but it is pretty good (sometimes very). The problem when you think about it is obvious, it is too short. The scenario gives us a large and varied handful of people, perhaps too many to fit into a one hundred minute story. As a result, Crash feels a little underdeveloped, and pretty contrived. Despite that, the drama is solid, the acting is superb, and the movie's intentions are noble. Probably a film worth seeing.

Set up a little like Pulp Fiction, with shorter scenes, Crash intertwines the lives of various people living in the darker parts of Los Angeles. Among them: a racist but dedicated cop, a middle eastern shop keeper on the verge of bankruptcy, a pair of street thieves, and a young couple going through marriage trouble, after receiving police abuse one night.

Crash is not a movie to fall in love with, but it is a respectable motion picture that is able to make do with what it has.

title: No-One is Wholly Good or Wholly Evil
review:
"Crash" is often described as an "anti-racist" film, but it does not fit the normal template for issue movies about racism, which normally deal with some injustice perpetrated by white racists against blacks (often in the Deep South) and with the efforts of black people, often assisted by liberal whites, to combat that injustice. "Crash", which is set in Los Angeles, has a complex plot consisting of a number of separate, but interlocking, sub-plots dealing with various aspects of racial tensions in the city. The cast is made up not solely of Caucasians and African-Americans but also contains Hispanics, Koreans, Chinese and Iranians. The title refers not only to an actual car crash which plays an important part in the plot but also to the ways in which people "crash" into one another when their lives collide.

The plot is too complex to summarise here. Some of the main characters, however, are the following:- Rick Cabot, the city's white District Attorney and his wife Jean.

Anthony, an African American car thief and Peter Waters, his Anthony's friend and partner in crime.

Graham Waters, Peter's brother. Whereas Peter has chosen a criminal lifestyle, Graham has made a career for himself as a detective on the police force.

John Ryan, a bigoted white police officer and Tommy Hansen, his partner.

Cameron Thayer, a black television director and his wife Christine.

Daniel Ruiz, a Mexican-American locksmith.

Farhad, an Iranian shopkeeper.

Although the main characters are drawn from a variety of different racial backgrounds, many of them (and some of the minor characters as well) are guilty of displaying racial attitudes- not prejudice towards blacks, but also prejudice towards whites, towards Hispanics, towards Asians and towards Middle Easterners. Even those who are the victims of prejudice themselves may also display it towards other races. Farhad, for example, experiences racial harassment from white Americans, who mistakenly refer to him as an "Arab", but his reaction makes it clear that he finds this offensive because he himself dislikes Arabs and resents being taken for one. Other characters may not display racism in the sense of prejudice towards another race or favouritism towards their own, but are nevertheless prepared to exploit racial tensions for their own ends. An example is Cabot, who is prepared to manipulate the evidence against a white cop accused of shooting a black colleague in the hope that this will win him votes among the black community.

Yet, despite the prejudices they display, most of the characters are not wholly evil. One character who seems to have aroused particular controversy is that of Ryan. In one scene he is seen to be abusing his authority by sexually molesting Christine under the pretext of searching for weapons. Yet in a later scene he bravely and selflessly risks his life in order to rescue from a burning car a woman who, in an ironic twist, turns out to be Christine herself. Ryan's racist attitudes are explained in terms of the damage done to his father's business by local affirmative action policies.

What is so controversial about Ryan is that he offends against our preconceptions (about movie characters if not about real life individuals) that a person who commits one base action will inevitably prove to be an irredeemably corrupt villain in all other respects. Ryan, in fact, is only one example of a theme running throughout the film, the idea that no person can be regarded as wholly evil or wholly good. This idea is applied generally, not merely to questions of racial attitudes. Anthony, for example, seems at first sight to be a thoroughly unpleasant individual, yet at the end of the film he saves a group of illegal Asian immigrants from a life of virtual slavery, even though he does not like "Chinamen", as he calls them.

On the other hand, characters who initially appear admirable show that they have a dark side. Hansen at first seems to be a liberal; he requests a transfer because he is offended by his partner Ryan's racist attitudes. Later, however, he shoots a young black man dead when he over-reacts during an argument. Graham also appears at first sight to be a conscientious officer, but he later agrees to withhold evidence and thereby pervert the course of justice in order to have the District Attorney drop a case against his brother Peter. (Ironically, Peter turns out to be the man killed by Hansen).

I must admit that I have never seen "Brokeback Mountain", so am unable to enter into the controversy as to whether that film should have beaten "Crash" to the Best Picture Oscar in 2005. I can, however, say that "Crash" is an excellent film which certainly makes a worthy winner. It is a good example of ensemble acting, with all the cast making a valuable contribution, even though there are no outstanding star performances. It has an intelligent, well-written script which asks some difficult questions, not just about racial issues but also about human nature in general. It is not, however, a dry, abstract exercise in social or moral philosophy but also a powerful human drama with a number of emotionally gripping scenes. Occasionally the complexity of the plot makes it difficult to follow, and there seem to be one of two loose ends, but overall this is a very good film indeed. It is remarkable that Paul Haggis, the co-writer, co-producer and director had previously directed only one feature film, "Red Hot" eleven years earlier. 8/10

title: ldsnipes

title: Social Construction
review:
How could someone be born into a multicultural society and still see only what the naked eye lets you? There are no words to describe this kind of hatred; there are no words to explain this injustice. This interesting point is brought before the world, and the world is deceived with the inevitability of the fact that everyone has their justification. The justification that everyone has to pursue because there is no other choice, this justification would be death. The movie "Crash" written by Mark Lewison; acts as a mirror into the minds and hearts of everyday people. This movie lets us view who we (humanity), really are; and we are detestable and an undeserved people.

The setting is a Los Angeles involving characters that are inter-related to each other without even realizing this. There in the big city live these people with their opinions about everyone else except for themselves. These characters seem to have everyone else figured out, but what about their own lives? What about the configuring and bewildering issues that dwell in their own homes? There are at least seven situations involved in this story line and every one of these situations there is someone that is judging someone else for their construed information about their personal ethnic heritage. These problems are the key factor in this movie, to overcome and understand the real meaning of abhorrence of another person's race. To find out what it really means to be a person of the underlined text, and that is hope. Hope for the next person to come along and pick up where we left off at; and that place is understanding. To understand another people that are not from your own, traditionally we may call that wisdom.

To my understanding, as I watched this movie that was portrayed by brave characters, I see how humanity is reacting who we really are. As for the human race, we may have been one of those characters in that movie; we maybe under motivated and uncultivated too much for our own good. All I know is that this cycle has to stop somewhere and sometime soon.

title: Good guys and bad guys...
review: The outrage surrounding this picture is again created by people who, though they have every right to their strong opinions, simply cannot grasp the truth behind the meaning. If you haven't lived a chunk of the many lives beautifully portrayed in this tight little film, its going to miss your exit and take you into unfamiliar territory. Many, if not most people go to the movies for the simple entertainment value, where as others go in order to seek out something familiar and often painful within themselves. The former movie goer is eager to see something where there are good guys and bad guys and despite seemingly insurmountable odds, the good guy prevails at the last moment, creating a perfect circle of meaning and the ultimate satisfaction that good triumphs over evil; a happy little package with a perfectly tied bow. The latter film-goer however, comes in with the understanding that life, or at least a brief glimpse into people's lives, is a linear event, often not turning out in happy endings or even providing endings at all. It is with this understanding that the viewing of this film must be undertaken. Prepare yourself to initially misunderstand or even hate a character and then suddenly kick yourself for having been so short sighted. Like the real lives that people live every day, this film either runs through your neighborhood or is just another unfamiliar place that you never would have known to exist.

title: Amazing and Ethereal Performances & music

title: Fast-paced and prejudiced
review: A film entirely about prejudice and consequence, it delves a lot deeper than I thought it would, as I - prejudiced as I was - had heard a lot about it, mainly critique saying that even though the film's made to make people question their own readymade ideas that aren't based on rational thinking, that's exactly what it did. I'll happily say I think those critics are wrong. In my opinion, the film points out prejudice in the viewer and yes, I'm one of the persons who thinks everybody is prejudiced about a lot of things, even though some of us may be scared to admit it at first. This film is a good step towards realising this, by plainly showing how racism, nationalism and other isms play a daily role in our lives. Fast-paced, catchy, horrible and funny, I strongly recommend it.
