title: Crash!
review: Unlike any other inspiration movies I have ever seen, Crash is by far the most influential movie. But in addition to the wonder movie plot, acting story line, I have many negative things to say about the movie as well. First of all, I believe it's important to recognize this movie as one of the most motivated film ever made. The topic of the movie is racism in America. However Paul Haggis, director, focused this problem in Los Angeles because of its hectic nature. The story introduces many characters with different ethnicity and slow brings these characters into each other's life. All of these characters are diverse of the way they live life, but they're also similar in the way that they accepts the hidden racism that's affecting the world everyday. The movie portrays the typical racial stereotypes and shows that it's an evitable concept that is here to stay in our community forever. In one scenario, a white woman Jean Cabot, played by Sandra Bullock, become extremely racist after being pointed with a gun during her encounter with two black men on the street. When Jean saw the locksmith, Daniel, installing new locks on her door, she demands to her husband Rick, played by Brendan Fraser, to have those locks removed because Daniel is Mexican. The movie is so emotionally packed with radical circumstances that Haggis leaves the audiences no room to decide who are justified and who aren't. Ludicrous' character is an example of this confusion. He plays Anthony, a black gang member who is extremely self-conscious about his ethnicity. During many moments when he's faced with a White man, automatically Anthony assumes the man is making typical black racial comments. The problem is this is that most of the times, he's the one who keeps refer back to the racist comments others had made about his people. This leaves me the impression that he's actually more racists about his ethnicity than what the society has placed upon him. The actors were phenomenal for portraying their appropriate role. Of all the characters I find Daniel, played by Michael Pena, especially convincing. Daniel is a young hardworking Hispanic immigrant with a loving wife and a beautiful na√Øve daughter Lara. Because of their low income, the family is forced to live in a criminal environment. The father daughter scene was truly moving. When Daniel comes home from work, he finds Lara hiding under her bed scared by the sound of guns outside her window. As an affectionate father, Daniel tells Lara the story of an imaginary guardian angel who gave him a 'charm' which will always protect him from any evil. Then he passes the 'charm' to Lara and kissed her to sleep. Lara, now wearing the 'charm', is convinced that she's protected from all harm. So when the Persian storeowner who is convinced that the Mexican will rob his store, he fires the gun to Daniel as Lara jumps in front of her father to protect him. Daniel screams and breaks down to tears while holding Lara in his arms. The feeling of witnessing the situation is revolting. At first you will feel petrified watching the little girl resting on the father's shoulders as he screams in despair. But sudden you'll find yourself speechless as you see the girl slowly look up to her father. The bullet missed Lara. How? That's what you should find out. I respect the ending of the story. Unlike other movies, the director ended the story on a neutral tone. Instead of try to end racism, Haggis left the problem as it is. I believe this adds to the reason why the movie is so respected. Haggis' point is that racism is never endless when we have diverse people together in the same melting pot struggling for the competition of survival. It's the price we all have to pay for living in America. Even though the leaders of the country try hard to end racism, it's just impossible to achieve this idealistic notion. What I really liked about the whole movie is that it's not just a propaganda to stop discrimination, but it's also acts as a notion that allows individuals have their own understanding of the issue. Because the movie involves with characters of various race, more people will be able to relate themselves with the matter and hopefully react to it in an idealistic fashion. The negative thing I didn't like about the movie is the exaggerated and the unrealistic racial discriminations. I believe the director had embellished the issue a little too much. Taking the movie to a much personal account, I believe Haggis took the topic too dramatic to an extend that it's almost insulting. Not everyone in the city is as racists as the characters in the movie. Most of the people are too busy dealing with their own lives rather than getting into other's lives. Just like police Graham had said in the opening of the movie, "You brush past people, people bump into you. In L.A., nobody touches you. We're always behind this metal and glass. I think we miss that touch so much, that we crash into each other, just so we can feel something."

title: Haggis Brings the Melting Pot to a Boil
review:
A black detective barters to save his felon brother from life in prison. A white officer of the LAPD struggles with his dying father's HMO. A Hispanic locksmith works to keep his wife and daughter out of the dangerous neighborhood they've left behind. What do all of these people have in common? They are just a few characters in the three-time-Oscar-winning film entitled, Crash, who find themselves battling and, often simultaneously, contributing to the common racial prejudices that plague modern-day Los Angeles. While the theme is often force-fed at times, the powerful music, suspenseful plot, superb acting, thrilling cinematography and vivid character development make this a prized film of our time.

Writer and director Paul Haggis takes us on a roller-coaster ride of emotions from the disparity and anguish that each character experiences to their ultimate chance at redemption. For Officer John Ryan played by Oscar-nominated actor Matt Dillon, the story begins with a phone call to his father's health insurance company. He pleads with a black female representative who tells him they cannot help his father. Angry and frustrated, Dillon's character deliberately stops a car carrying a black husband and wife and gropes the woman. Her husband, a successful producer played by Terrance Howard, chooses to sit back and do nothing to preserve his reputation. At the same time, Officer Ryan's white partner serves as a disturbed onlooker, unwilling to take a stand against the injustice. Ryan later sums up the film when he tells him, "you think you know who you are¬Ö you have no idea."

The theme of the film, though forced at times, is both simple and critical. We shouldn't judge those around us based on racial, sexual or any other prejudices. The characters in the film make this painfully obvious throughout their development. A previously judgmental black carjacker played by Ludicrous is given a wake-up call and a second chance. The once prejudice wife of the city's District Attorney finds an unlikely friend at a time when she needs one most. The theme applies to the network of characters whose lives eventually and profoundly "crash" into one another by story's end.

The choice of Haggis to use Christmas in Los Angeles as the film's setting is remarkably befitting, presenting a sort of ironic seasonal imagery throughout the story. While Christmas tends to carry with it the connotation of holiday cheer, Haggis challenges this by accompanying it with a slew of dismal events in a city that rarely sees snowfall. Also noteworthy is Haggis' choice to use a racially diverse city like Los Angeles and a notoriously racist organization like the LAPD to convey the theme. These examples of Haggis' creativity prove effective as characters from different backgrounds collide.

As with all great films, the music in Crash is moving and plot-appropriate. Music producer and composer Mark Isham takes hold of our spirits and doesn't let go. One particular example of this is shown through the gripping scene where the store owner stands before the locksmith, pointing a gun. This scene, together with the music, is so powerful it sends the proverbial chill down the spines of its audience. With Isham, composer of music from such films as Miracle, Bobby, and Oscar-nominated ¬¨A River Runs Through It, Crash will have you putting a hand over your heart (IMDB.com).

Another element of the film that adds to its tone is its abundance of great actors. Those not previously mentioned include Don Cheadle as the black detective, Jennifer Esposito as Ria, Brendan Fraser as the DA and Sandra Bullock as the DA's wife. Matt Dillon's portrayal of Officer Ryan is especially captivating. Rarely does a film come along that makes us truly feel and understand the characters and their situations. The convincing acting of such a stellar cast adds to the credibility of the film's message.

Lastly, what credibility does a film offer without realistic and creative cinematography? Steadicam operator and cinematographer James Muro makes us feel we are right there with the characters. Muro shines through Crash from his experience filming blockbuster hits such as Miami Vice, Titanic and Terminator 2 (IMDB.com). From the scene where Officer Ryan struggles to save the trapped woman from her burning car to the scene where snow finally comes to Los Angeles, Muro's camera work brings us to the action, once again, making the movie all the more effective.

There is little wonder why Crash is so highly acclaimed. Its iconoclastic theme begs us to learn to change. First-rate acting and dramatic music bring credibility to the already captivating storyline. Fresh cinematography creates realism and the crisp character development makes us sympathize. No other film makes us think more about how we treat others or how we give in to prejudice. Perhaps only in dire times of need do we disregard our differences and work together to save ourselves from peril.

title: The work is poignant. Its statement: trust and sincerity.
review:
The movie Crash, co-written, directed, and produced by Paul Haggis, is an image of honesty, violence, truth, and irony projected beautifully onto the screen. Crash was nominated for six Academy Awards and won Oscars for best picture and best original screenplay in 2004. The plot intertwines people of all genders, ages, and races into a braided rope of human unity.

The works of Paul Haggis can not be looked upon as trivial. Nearly ever screenplay he has written has claimed success. Among the list is Academy Award winner Million Dollar Baby, and Flags of Our Fathers. In 2003 Razor magazine published a list of, "nonconformists that defy dictates, the iconoclasts that cling to independent thought, the radicals that refuse adherence - that give us pause. They are what legends are made of." And sitting within the top 25 was Paul Haggis. After watching Crash, it is evident why.

"It's the sense of touch. In any real city, you walk, you know? You brush past people, people bump into you. In L.A., nobody touches you. We're always behind this metal and glass. I think we miss that touch so much, that we crash into each other, just so we can feel something."

These were the first and the last words spoken in the movie, and they give an excellent depiction of what diction can be expected while watching. Almost every word provokes thought, so this movie is not one to catch on a light-hearted whim.

The characters in Crash are presented and are almost immediately developed. There is no superficial, graceful entry into their lives; instead the audience is harshly, honestly, and abruptly thrown into each character's engagements. Through a series of their actions and consequences, the movie emphasizes how vital it is for human kind (despite race, age, or gender) to be honest with each other.

The work is poignant. Its statement: trust and sincerity are the only things that will keep humankind sane and progressive.

title: Isolation & Prejudice
review: This movie about people (meaning you and me) is brilliantly structured. The difficult task of blending multiple stories into a convincing whole without any trace of artificiality or exaggerated sentimentality is an admirable achievement.Life as it is with the increasing tendency of present-day man to isolate himself and hide behind prejudices towards others as a form of survival in a mad, mad world. Not a moralizing or judgemental approach as to what we are as human beings but an illustration of the complex aspects of our nature and how easily good can turn to bad and vice versa. Our narrow-minded outlook on the world around us and how easily we debase individuals by defining them as belonging to an inferior class or race is the main theme on which the movie is based. The issue however is not that simple and the most important aspect of this movie is that it sees things as they really are: our urban environment and our personal experiences with people in general do not encourage real confidence in our fellow man. There remains however a glimmer of hope and the message "Crash" conveys is that by gaining insight into the fact that our attitudes in general are based more on the unforeseen and casual incidents we experience in everyday life than on our so-called deep convictions, we could (possibly) become better people.A lot of reviews consider the movie weak due to its radical and therefore limited analysis of racism in general and that it focuses too often on a form of cheap emotional content. But let's be honest: isn't that precisely the only way most people in the real world function?
