Although there is an overall sense of disconnectedness in the film, its funny how at the end, everything falls in place and you have come full circle. Another smart move by director Paul Haggis was not including any subtitles, this way only the specific culture in the audience who speaks the same language as the character will understand what they are talking about, just like in real life. This movie connects people.

Like many other pictures before it, Crash tries to illustrate to the audience what it feels like to be the minority. However, with this film, everyone in the audience is the minority. It doesn't leave anyone out of it. Black, white, brown, yellow, ¬Ö Asian, Middle-Eastern, Latino, African; everyone steps into each other's shoes for 115 minutes. Just about any racial statement or stereotype is brought out in the film. There is no hero, there is no super-villain, there is not one character you absolutely despise, and no one you cheer for. Do not expect to come out of this movie anticipating someone has won a battle. No race comes out on top, it shows us how any race is willing to make judgments about others even if they have been oppressed before. It is also a film about redemption. By the end, of the film, a few people you wish wouldn't die, do, other who you wouldn't expect to do good deeds, do, others find redemption spiritually, and some find it through a friend.

If you haven't seen it yet, you better soon.

title: Intrigueing look at racism in Los Angeles
review:
What this film does that others haven't in the past is have the subject of racism brought to the forefront from the perspective of all the characters and how small things that occur can have a major impact even with those who are not directly involved. Story is about how several characters living in the Los Angeles area deal with racism and how it effects their lives and everyone around them including a black cop named Graham (Don Cheadle) who is sleeping with his female partner Ria (Jennifer Esposito) but has no idea of which Latin descent she's from.

*****SPOILER ALERT***** Other characters involve a district attorney (Brendan Fraser) and his wife (Sandra Bullock) and how they deal with being carjacked from two black men (Ludacris & Larenz Tate) who have their own perspective of things. A white racist cop named Ryan (Matt Dillon) harasses a black couple (Terrence Howard & Thandie Newton) while his disgusted partner Hanson (Ryan Phillippe) looks on and an Iranian store owner has his business looted and blames the Hispanic locksmith.

This is made by Paul Haggis (Million Dollar Baby) who makes his directorial debut with this effort and not only does his script cover all the bases but his attention to detail is at times overwhelming. In my perfect film world this would be considered the normal attempt in making a film but instead audiences are used to wading through about 10 or so bad films before finally viewing something thought provoking such as this. As much as I respected this film I still came away thinking that it was flawed in some manner and I think what hurts this is that there is just too many characters and events being tossed at the viewer. Even so, Haggis's effort deserves praise not only in what he's trying to achieve but by pushing the right buttons and provoking the audience with a subject that (let's face it) makes everyone uncomfortable. Haggis has emerged as a true talent and an important artist and he seems to be one of those writer/directors who even if he fails he'll still create something that's worth everyone's time.

title: Head on Crash You Won't Recover Easily From
review:
I knew when I saw the previews for Crash, that it was going to be a movie that I would enjoy, but I didn't know how much. It wasn't even until the day before I saw it in theaters that I realized it was focused primarily on racism, nor did I know that it was being directed by Paul Haggis, the mind behind Million Dollar Baby. So, I went in to this one pretty open to anything that was thrown my way.

I won't spoil anything and I won't give a summary of the movie because enough people have done that before me, I will just say that from the opening to the ending, this movie grabs a hold of your throat and doesn't let go... forcing you to watch and listen as people criticize, call names, attack verbally and physically, people that they deem "different" and by the same token, inferior.

The thing about Crash that I think sticks out the most, is that anyone can place either themselves or someone they know in the shoes of anyone in the movie, from Bullock, to Cheadle, to Ludicrous, and even Ryan Phillipe, the one "good guy" in the movie. You can't help but put yourself in their situations and ask what you yourself would do and, by the same token, what you wouldn't do.

I will close by saying that people who can't handle racial slurs, foul language, and violence, probably shouldn't see this film, but at the same time I encourage everyone to see this film and embrace the politically incorrect reality of a movie like this that only comes along once in a couple years. Thank you Paul Haggis for making an entertaining movie that has a real message behind it, something lacking in most of the movies today.

title: LGF does it again
review: i have to say that i am becoming more and more of a fan of don cheadle each time i see him on the big screen. i thought this was a great movie, even though it was at times hard to stomach the overall racial tone of it. is LA really like this? i love LGF films and can't wait until High Tension and Saw 2 come out in the next few months. i recommend this movie to LGF fans, it won't disappoint. i had a strong feeling that the bullets that the Persian man bought were blanks...any other views see that one coming? also, has the Hispanic actor in Crash been in any other films? i thought he did a really good job. even Luda did a decent job in his real acting debut.

title: Would have liked it better if it were twice as long...
review: Crash takes on a number of important issues, though none that are particularly new to the screen. Though it attempts to deal with race in America in a provocative, original way, I left feeling like I barely new the characters in the film. This movie reminds me of a dramatic version of Love Actually - so many people, so little time. With half the characters I feel I would have gotten to know them better and enjoyed the picture more. The plots are interwoven in such a way that it really feels like you're watching a movie. A more realistic portrayal might have included more finely drawn personalities and fewer interconnected elements. Overall, an ambitious attempt at creating race dialogue that falls a bit short.
